revision.comment: added template {{About-Hugos}} to beginning of section "Awards", and deleted the text already transcluded by the template
revision.text:
{{Infobox convention | name = Baycon, the 26th World Science Fiction Convention | image = | caption = | status = | genre = [[Science fiction]] | venue = Hotel Claremont | location = [[Berkeley, California]] | country = United States | first = August 29-September 2, 1968 | last = | organizer = | filing = non-profit | attendance = 1,430 | website = }} The '''26th World Science Fiction Convention''', also known as '''Baycon''', was held August 29-September 2, 1968, at the Hotel Claremont in [[Berkeley, California]], United States. The Worldcon was combined with the annual West Coast Science Fantasy Conference ([[Westercon]]), sharing Guests of Honor and Chairmen. The chairmen were [[Bill Donaho]], Alva Rogers, and [[J. Ben Stark]]. The guests of honor were [[Philip José Farmer]] (pro) and [[Walter J. Daugherty]] (fan). The toastmaster was [[Robert Silverberg]]. Total attendance was approximately 1,430. ==Awards== {{About-Hugos}} ===Hugo Awards=== * [[Hugo Award for Best Novel|Best Novel]]: ''[[Lord of Light]]'' by [[Roger Zelazny]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Novella|Best Novella]]: ** "[[Weyr Search]]" by [[Anne McCaffrey]] and ** "[[Riders of the Purple Wage]]" by Philip José Farmer (tie) * [[Hugo Award for Best Novelette|Best Novelette]]: "[[Gonna Roll Them Bones]]" by [[Fritz Leiber]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Short Story|Best Short Story]]: "[[I Have No Mouth, and I Must Scream]]" by [[Harlan Ellison]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation|Best Dramatic Presentation]]: "[[The City on the Edge of Forever]]" (''[[Star Trek: The Original Series|Star Trek]]'' episode, original script by Harlan Ellison) * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Artist|Best Professional Artist]]: [[Jack Gaughan]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Professional Magazine|Best Professional Magazine]]: ''[[if (magazine)|if]]'' * [[Hugo Award for Best Fanzine|Best Fanzine]]: ''[[Amra (magazine)|Amra]]'', edited by [[George Scithers]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fan Artist|Best Fan Artist]]: [[George Barr (artist)|George Barr]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fan Writer|Best Fan Writer]]: [[Ted White (author)|Ted White]] ===Other awards=== * [[Worldcon Special Award|Special Award]]: Harlan Ellison for ''[[Dangerous Visions]]'' * Special Award: [[Gene Roddenberry]] for ''[[Star Trek]]'' ==Notable events== This Worldcon was the first one that was attended by large numbers of people in the [[hippie subculture]]. A [[psychedelic art|psychedelic]] [[liquid light show|light show]] was presented in the main ballroom of the hotel. [[Robert Silverberg]] gave a speech about using [[LSD]] to attain a [[mystical experience]]. [[Harlan Ellison]] read a story he had written about a hippie commune. [[Poul Anderson]] emceed a presentation by the [[Society for Creative Anachronism]]. ==See also== *[[World Science Fiction Society]] ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite web|first=Richard |last=Lynch |work=Fan History of the 1960s |title=Chapter Eight: Worldcons of the 1960s |url=http://www.smithway.org/history/chap8a.html |date=March 29, 1996 |accessdate=September 30, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927132045/http://www.smithway.org/history/chap8a.html |archivedate=September 27, 2011 |df= }} }} == External links == *[http://www.nesfa.org/data/LL/TheLongList.html NESFA.org: The Long List] *[http://www.nesfa.org/data/LL/LongListNotes.html#1968 NESFA.org: 1968 convention notes] *[http://www.thehugoawards.org/content/pdf/1968HugoAwardsCeremonyTranscription.pdf Transcript of the 1968 Hugo Awards Ceremony] {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[25th World Science Fiction Convention]]
Nycon 3 in [[New York City|New York]], USA (1967) | title = [[List of Worldcons]] | years = '''26th World Science Fiction Convention'''
Baycon in [[Oakland, California|Oakland]], USA (1968) | after = [[27th World Science Fiction Convention]]
St. Louiscon in [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]], USA (1969) }} {{s-end}} {{World Science Fiction Convention}} {{DEFAULTSORT:World Science Fiction Convention 026}} [[Category:1968 in the United States]] [[Category:World Science Fiction Convention]] [[Category:Science fiction conventions in the United States]] [[Category:1968 in California]] [[Category:1968 conferences]] {{sf-convention-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''[[Martti Ahtisaari|Ahtisaari]] Plan''', formally the '''Comprehensive Proposal for the Kosovo Status Settlement''' ('''CSP'''), is a status settlement proposal covering a wide range of issues related to the [[Kosovo status process]] for [[Kosovo]].<ref>{{citation|title=Letter dated 26 March 2007 from the Secretary-General addressed to the President of the Security Council |publisher=[[United Nations Security Council]] |date=26 March 2007 |at=Annex |url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/retrieveattachments?openagent&shortid=YZHG-6ZNTVS&file=Full_Report.pdf |archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20071214235411/http%3A//www.reliefweb.int/rw/RWFiles2007.nsf/FilesByRWDocUnidFilename/YZHG%2D6ZNTVS%2Dfull_report.pdf/%24File/full_report.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=14 December 2007 }}</ref>
Some of the main components of the plan include the formation of the [[International Steering Group for Kosovo]] (ISG), and the [[International Civilian Representative for Kosovo]] (ICR), the [[European Union Special Representative]] (EUSR) for Kosovo, appointed by the [[Council of the European Union]].<ref name="plan-art4.1">{{citation|title=Letter dated 26 March 2007 from the Secretary-General addressed to the President of the Security Council, Addendum, Comprehensive Proposal for the Kosovo Status Settlement, Annex IX, International Civilian Representative |publisher=[[United Nations Security Council]] |date=26 March 2007 |at=article 4.1 |url=http://www.unosek.org/docref/Comprehensive_proposal-english.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091009130102/http://www.unosek.org/docref/Comprehensive_proposal-english.pdf |archivedate=9 October 2009 }}</ref><ref name="plan-art12.1">{{citation|title=Letter dated 26 March 2007 from the Secretary-General addressed to the President of the Security Council, Addendum, Comprehensive Proposal for the Kosovo Status Settlement |publisher=[[United Nations Security Council]] |date=26 March 2007 |at=article 12.1 |url=http://www.unosek.org/docref/Comprehensive_proposal-english.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091009130102/http://www.unosek.org/docref/Comprehensive_proposal-english.pdf |archivedate=9 October 2009 }}</ref>
In early 2012 President [[Boris Tadić]] recommended his Five-Point Plan for Kosovo, essentially an upgrade of the Ahtisaari Plan.
On 10 September 2012, the International Steering Group had its final meeting<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ico-kos.org/f/pdf/COMMUNIQUE16thISG-Eng.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-01-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022143615/http://www.ico-kos.org/f/pdf/COMMUNIQUE16thISG-Eng.pdf |archivedate=2013-10-22 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ico-kos.org/?id=61|title=Ending of supervised independence 10 September 2012|publisher=International Civilian Office|accessdate=6 January 2013}}</ref> and formally ended its supervision,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.ria.ru/world/20120910/175884680.html|title=International Steering Group Ends Kosovo Supervision|author=Sputnik|date=10 September 2012|publisher=}}</ref> {{quotation|With immediate effect, the CSP no longer exists as a separate and superior legal power, and the Constitution of the Republic of Kosovo now constitutes the sole basis for the country’s legal framework.}} and Kosovo became responsible for its own governance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ico-kos.org/f/pdf/COMMUNIQUE16thISG-Eng.pdf |title=Sixteenth and final meeting of the International Steering Group for Kosovo |date=10 September 2012 |publisher=International Civilian Office |accessdate=6 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022143615/http://www.ico-kos.org/f/pdf/COMMUNIQUE16thISG-Eng.pdf |archivedate=22 October 2013 |df= }}</ref>
==Overview== The proposal included provisions covering:
* Constitutional provisions * Rights of Communities and their Members * Decentralization of local government * Justice system * Religious and cultural heritage * International debt * Property and archives * Kosovo security sector * [[International Civilian Representative]] * [[European Security and Defense Policy]] (ESDP) [[EU mission in Kosovo|Rule of Law mission]] * International Military Presence (such as continuation of KFOR) * Legislative agenda
While not yet mentioning the word "independence," the it included several provisions that were widely interpreted as implying statehood for Kosovo. For example, it would give Kosovo the right to apply for membership in international organizations, create a Kosovo Security Force and adopt national symbols.<ref>"[https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20070202/ts_afp/serbiakosovounstatusproposal_070202162726;_ylt=Ap9g4N..BOD23p6b5WY2sqsXxHcA;_ylu=X3oDMTBiMW04NW9mBHNlYwMlJVRPUCUl UN envoy seeks multi-ethnic, self-governing Kosovo] ", ''Agence France-Presse'' (AFP), Vienna, 2 February 2007.</ref>
==History== [[Martti Ahtisaari]] stated, on 8 February 2007, that after a period of consultations with the parties, he would finalize his Settlement proposal for submission to the UN Security Council, when he would also elaborate on the status issue itself.<ref>"[https://web.archive.org/web/20070926213916/http://www.unosek.org/pressrelease/2007-02-08-Press_Conference_by_SE_Martti_Ahtisaari,_in_NY_.doc Ahtisaari press conference] ", ''UNOSEK website'' , New York, 8 February 2007.</ref>
In Belgrade, [[Prime Minister of Serbia|Serbian Prime Minister]] [[Vojislav Koštunica]] refused to receive Ahtisaari. Koštunica claimed that because Serbia had still not formed a new government after the January 21 parliamentary elections he had no mandate to discuss Kosovo and therefore could not meet Ahtisaari. Nevertheless, he later denounced the proposal as "illegitimate and unacceptable" because he alleged it "violates the U.N. Charter ... by undermining sovereignty of U.N. member Serbia."<ref>"[http://voanews.com/english/2007-02-02-voa51.cfm UN Envoy Presents Kosovo Plan, Serbia Quickly Rejects It] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070204060433/http://www.voanews.com/english/2007-02-02-voa51.cfm |date=2007-02-04 }} ", by Barry Wood, ''[[Voice of America]]'' (VOA), Washington, 2 February 2007.</ref><ref>[http://www.srbija.gov.rs/vesti/vest.php?id=31550 "Ahtisaari's proposal unacceptable and illegitimate for Serbia"], Government of the Republic of Serbia website, Belgrade, 7 February 2007.</ref> President [[Boris Tadić]] did receive Ahtisaari, after which he reaffirmed his vow to never accept an independent Kosovo.<ref>"[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/un_kosovo;_ylt=Ao.rrNE3_hxI1gVTsCEJYhkXxHcA;_ylu=X3oDMTBiMW04NW9mBHNlYwMlJVRPUCUl U.N. envoy unveils Kosovo proposal] ", by Garentina Kraja, ''[[Associated Press]]'' (AP), Pristina, 2 February 2007.</ref> Foreign Minister [[Vuk Drašković]] warned that it was "necessary to avoid an imposed solution that could cause Serbia to become a factor of instability."<ref>[http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/02/07/europe/EU-GEN-Serbia-EU.php "Serbian leaders warn UN plan for Kosovo could destabilize Balkans"], ''[[International Herald Tribune]]'', Belgrade, 7 February 2007.</ref>
In Pristina, Kosovo Albanian leaders issued a statement after meeting with Ahtisaari saying they are "convinced that the international process for the resolution of Kosovo's status led by President Ahtisaari will be concluded soon with Kosovo becoming an independent state."<ref>"Unity Team Press Statement," 2 February 2007.</ref>
The United States called the proposal "fair and balanced,"<ref>[https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2007/february/79774.htm Presentation of Kosovo Status Proposal to the Parties] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171006013500/https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2007/february/79774.htm |date=2017-10-06 }}, Sean McCormack, U.S. Department of State spokesman, Washington, DC, 2 February 2007.</ref> while the EU Presidency noted that Ahtisaari's proposals "build on almost twelve months of direct talks between Belgrade and Pristina."<ref>[http://www.eu2007.de/en/News/CFSP_Statements/February/0202Kosovo.html EU Presidency Statement on the Kosovo status proposals to be presented today by Martti Ahtisaari in Belgrade and Pristina] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070208061300/http://www.eu2007.de/en/News/CFSP_Statements/February/0202Kosovo.html |date=2007-02-08 }}, 2 February 2007.</ref>
On 21 February, Ahtisaari began a period of consultations with the parties in Vienna to finalize the Settlement. He made clear that his proposal was a draft and that he would incorporate compromise solutions into the final document. After this period of consultations and further modification of the Settlement, Ahtisaari convened a high-level meeting of the parties in Vienna on March 10. After this meeting, leaders from both sides signaled a total unwillingness to compromise on their central demands (Kosovo Albanians for Kosovo's independence; Serbia for continued sovereignty over Kosovo). Concluding that there was no chance for the two sides to reconcile their positions, Ahtisaari said he intended to submit to the UN Security Council his proposed status recommendations, including an explicit recommendation for the status outcome itself, by the end of March.
In November 2008, the EU accepted the demand of Serbia not to implement the plan of Ahtisaari through EULEX.<ref>{{cite web|author=BalkanInsight.com |url=http://www.sofiaecho.com/article/eu-accepts-belgrade-s-conditions-for-eulex/id_32852/catid_68 |title=EU accepts Belgrade’s conditions for EULEX |publisher=Sofiaecho.com |date=2008-11-07 |accessdate=2010-04-28}}</ref>
==Reaction== {{main|10 February 2007 protest in Kosovo}} On February 10, 2007, [[Kosovo Albanians]] protested against the Ahtisaari Plan.<ref>{{cite news |title=Amnesty Seeks Justice for Killed Kosovo Protesters |url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/amnesty-calls-un-to-bring-justice-to-two-killed-kosovo-albanians-02-09-2017 |accessdate=7 October 2018}}</ref> Two were killed and others seriously injured after [[Romanian Police]] serving in the UN Interim Administration Mission in Kosovo, UNMIK, fired rubber bullets at the demonstrators.<ref>{{cite news |title=Amnesty Seeks Justice for Killed Kosovo Protesters |url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/amnesty-calls-un-to-bring-justice-to-two-killed-kosovo-albanians-02-09-2017 |accessdate=7 October 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Kosovo peace process]] [[Category:Martti Ahtisaari|Plan]] [[Category:Kosovo–Serbia relations]] [[Category:Politics of Serbia]] [[Category:Politics of Kosovo]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Election | election_name = Algerian legislative election, 2002 | country = Algeria | type = parliamentary | ongoing = no | previous_election = Algerian legislative election, 1997 | previous_year = 1997 | next_election = Algerian legislative election, 2007 | next_year = 2007 | seats_for_election = All 389 seats to the [[People's National Assembly]]
195 seats were needed for a majority | election_date = 30 May 2002 | image1 = [[File:Bouteflika (Algiers, Feb 2006).jpeg|100px]] | leader1 = [[Abdelaziz Bouteflika]] | party1 = National_Liberation_Front_(Algeria) | colour1 = | alliance1 = | leaders_seat1 = | last_election1 = 62 | seats1 = '''199''' | seat_change1 = '''{{increase}}137''' | popular_vote1 = '''2,618,003''' | percentage1 = '''34.3%''' | swing1 = '''{{increase}}20%''' | colour2 = 19481D | image2 = [[File:Abdellah Djaballah.jpg|105px]] | leader2 = [[Abdallah Djaballah]] | alliance2 = | party2 = Movement for National Reform | leaders_seat2 = | last_election2 = - | seats2 = 43 | seat_change2 = {{increase}}43 | popular_vote2 = 705,319 | percentage2 =9.5% | swing2 = {{increase}}9.5% | colour3 = | image3 = [[File:Ahmed Ouyahia.jpg|110px]] | leader3 = [[Ahmed Ouyahia]] | alliance3 = | party3 = National_Rally_for_Democracy_(Algeria) | leaders_seat3 = | last_election3 = 156 | seats3 = 47 | seat_change3 = {{decrease}}109 | popular_vote3 = 610,461 | percentage3 =8.2% | swing3 = {{decrease}}25.5% | title = Prime Minister | before_election = [[Ali Benflis]] | after_election = [[Ali Benflis]] | before_party = National_Liberation_Front_(Algeria) | after_party = National_Liberation_Front_(Algeria) }} {{Politics of Algeria}} The '''2002 Algerian Legislative election''' was held in [[Algeria]] on 30 May 2002 to elect members of the [[People's National Assembly]]. The governing [[National Liberation Front (Algeria)|National Liberation Front]] (FLN) won a majority of seats in the election. The election suffered from a low turnout, violence and boycotts by some opposition parties. ==Candidates== The election saw 10,052 candidates standing in the election from 23 [[List of political parties in Algeria|political parties]]. Of the candidates, 694 were female and 1,266 were independents.{{cite web| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/monitoring/media_reports/2013000.stm | title = Guide to Algeria elections | accessdate = 2008-08-01 | date = 2002-05-28 | publisher = ''[[BBC Online]]''}} ==Campaign== [[President of Algeria|President]] [[Abdelaziz Bouteflika]] announced the date of the election on 20 February and the official campaign began on 9 May.{{cite web| url = http://aceproject.org/ero-en/regions/africa/DZ/Algeria%20-%20A400686_24062002.pdf/view | title = Algeria - Diminishing Returns: Algeria’s 2002 Legislative Elections(ICG Report) | accessdate = 2008-08-01 | date = 2002-05-28 | publisher = ''ACE Electoral Knowledge Network''}} The President vowed that they would be free elections and warned people against undermining them.{{cite web| url = http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,54028,00.html | title = Algeria Holds Elections, and Few Care | accessdate = 2008-08-02 | date = 2002-05-30 | publisher = ''[[Fox News Channel]]''}} However five opposition parties boycotted the election, the [[Socialist Forces Front]] (FFS), [[Rally for Culture and Democracy]] (RCD), [[Republican National Alliance]] (ANR), [[Movement of Democrats and Socialists]] (MDS) and the [[Socialist Workers' Party (Algeria)|Socialist Workers' Party]] (PST). They claimed that previous elections in 1997 and 1999 were fraudulent and that this election would be no different.{{cite news| url = http://archives.cnn.com/2002/WORLD/africa/05/31/algeria.elections/index.html | title = Ruling party wins Algeria election | accessdate = 2008-08-01 | date = 2002-05-31 | publisher = ''[[CNN]]''}} A survey carried out by Al-Watan newspaper showed that 70% would vote for one of the 3 parties in the ruling coalition, the FLN, [[National Rally for Democracy (Algeria)|National Rally for Democracy]] and the [[Movement of Society for Peace]].{{cite web | url = http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2002/588/re8.htm | title = Berbers boycott polls | accessdate = 2008-08-02 | date = 2002-05-30 | publisher = ''[[Al-Ahram]]'' | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20081011073718/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2002/588/re8.htm | archive-date = 2008-10-11 | dead-url = yes | df = }} The FLN of [[Prime Minister of Algeria|Prime Minister]] [[Ali Benflis]] campaigned on a platform of unifying the different social groups of Algeria such as by [[regional development]] in the south. The RND, which had won the most seats at the [[Algerian legislative election, 1997|last election in 1997]], campaigned for [[Economic liberalism|economic liberalisation]] but was undermined by the lack of a base of support or a social ideology. The leader of the RND, [[Ahmed Ouyahia]], warned of the dangers of an [[Islamism|Islamist]] victory but his concerns were dismissed by the [[interior minister]]. The opposition [[Workers' Party (Algeria)|Workers' Party]] led by [[Louisa Hanoune]] campaigned against outside interference in Algeria and against [[privatisation]]. The campaign saw widespread apathy with many people seeing the parliament as toothless and the military as remaining the main power.{{cite web| url = http://www.sptimes.ru/index.php?action_id=2&story_id=7302 | title = Ruling NLF Makes Gains in Algerian Poll | accessdate = 2008-08-01 | date = 2002-06-04 | publisher = ''[[The St. Petersburg Times]]''}} The FLN attempted to raise interest in the election by doing things such as creating a rap song for younger people. However the poll by El Watan showed that over a third planned not to vote and in areas such as [[Bab el-Oued]] election billboards were mostly empty.{{cite web| url = http://allafrica.com/stories/200205300727.html | title = Algeria: Boycott, Violence Roil Algerian Elections | accessdate = 2008-08-02 | date = 2002-05-30 | publisher = ''[[AllAfrica.com]]''}} High unemployment, water and housing shortages were also seen as contributing to the apathy in the election. ===Election day=== On the day before the election 23 people were killed in [[Sendjas]] by the [[Armed Islamic Group]] (GIA) in continued violence from the [[Algerian Civil War]].{{cite news| url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2002/may/31/gilestremlett | title = Death and dissent as Algeria goes to polls | accessdate = 2008-08-02 | date = 2002-05-31 | publisher = ''[[guardian.co.uk]]'' | location=London | first=Giles | last=Tremlett}} On polling day itself security forces were out in force in [[Algiers]] with many [[roadblock]]s to prevent terrorist attacks. In the north eastern [[Kabylie]] region a [[general strike]] was organised and running battles took place in the regional capital [[Tizi Ouzou]] to try to prevent the election from taking place in the region. Throughout much of the area [[polling station]]s were deserted and many did not open at all.{{cite web| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/2015751.stm | title = Protesters boycott Algerian polls | accessdate = 2008-08-02 | date = 2002-05-30 | publisher = ''[[BBC Online]]''}} ==Results== The results saw the National Liberation Front win a clear majority of seats. The party won over triple the seats it won at the last election, going from 64 to 199 seats. The RND dropped from 156 seats to 47 in a disastrous result for the party.{{cite web| url = http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/algeria-90s.htm | title = Algerian Insurgency | accessdate = 2008-08-02 | publisher = ''GlobalSecurity.org''| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080814064347/http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/algeria-90s.htm| archivedate= 14 August 2008 | deadurl= no}} The moderate Islamist parties suffered a small overall decline in support, with the MSP losing half its seats but the [[Movement for National Reform]] made gains and won 43 seats. [[Voter turnout|Turnout]] in the election was the lowest yet since independence in 1962. Only 47% of the registered voters turned out to vote, compared to 63% in the 1997 election. 25 women were elected, 18 from the FLN, and after the election the number of women ministers was increased from one to five. {{Algerian parliamentary election, 2002}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Algerian elections}} [[Category:Algerian Civil War]] [[Category:Elections in Algeria]] [[Category:2002 elections in Africa]] [[Category:2002 in Algeria|Election]] [[Category:May 2002 events]]

revision.comment: removed grandparent category of [[Category:1989 in Georgia (country)]]
revision.text:
{{History of Georgia (country)}} {{Eastern Bloc sidebar}} The '''April 9 tragedy''' (also known as '''Tbilisi massacre''' or '''Tbilisi tragedy''') refers to the events in [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic]], on April 9, 1989, when an [[anti-Soviet]] (but pro-Stalin) demonstration was dispersed by the [[Soviet Army]], resulting in 21 deaths and hundreds of injuries. April 9 is now remembered as the '''Day of National Unity''' ({{lang-ka|ეროვნული ერთიანობის დღე}} ''erovnuli ertianobis dghe''), an annual [[Public holidays in Georgia|public holiday]].
==Prelude== The anti-Soviet movement became more active in the Georgian SSR in 1988. Several strikes and meetings were organized by anti-Soviet political organizations in Tbilisi. The conflict between the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] government and Georgian nationalists deepened after the so-called Lykhny Assembly on March 18, 1989, when several thousand [[Abkhaz people|Abkhaz]] demanded secession from Georgia and restoration of the Union republic status of 1921–1931. In response, the anti-Soviet groups organized a series of unsanctioned meetings across the republic, claiming that the Soviet government was using Abkhaz separatism in order to oppose the pro-independence movement.
The protests reached their peak on April 4, 1989, when tens of thousands of [[Georgian people|Georgians]] gathered before the House of Government on [[Rustaveli Avenue]] in Tbilisi. The protesters, led by the Independence Committee ([[Merab Kostava]], [[Zviad Gamsakhurdia]], [[Giorgi Chanturia]], Irakli Bathiashvili, Irakli Tsereteli and others) organized a peaceful demonstration and hunger strikes, demanding the punishment of Abkhaz secessionists and restoration of Georgian independence.<ref name="Sobchak">[http://sobchak.org/rus/docs/zakluchenie.htm Report of the Sobchak's commission of inquiry (in Russian)]</ref>
Local [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] authorities lost control over the situation in the capital and were unable to contain the protests. First Secretary of the Georgian Communist Party [[Jumber Patiashvili]] asked USSR leadership to send troops to restore order and impose curfew.<ref name="Sobchak"/>
==The demonstrations== In the evening of April 8, 1989, [[Colonel General]] [[Igor Rodionov]], Commander of the [[Transcaucasus Military District]], ordered his troops to mobilize. Moments before the attack by the Soviet forces, the Patriarch of Georgia [[Ilia II]] addressed the demonstrators asking them to leave [[Rustavelis Gamziri|Rustaveli Avenue]] and the vicinity of the government building due to the danger which accumulated during the day after appearance of Soviet tanks near the avenue. The demonstrators refused to disband even after the Patriarch's plea. The local Georgian [[militsiya]] (police) units were disarmed just before the operation.<ref name=Sobchak />
On April 9, at 3:45 a.m., Soviet [[Armoured personnel carrier|APCs]] and troops under General [[Igor Rodionov]] surrounded the demonstration area.<ref name=Sobchak /> Later, Rodionov claimed in his interview that groups of Georgian militants attacked unarmed soldiers with stones, metal chains and rods.<ref name ="Rodionov" >[http://www.warlib.ru/index.php?id=000064 Interview with Igor Rodionov]</ref> The Soviet troops received an order from General Rodionov to disband and clear the avenue of demonstrators by any means necessary.<ref name="ReferenceA">New Nations Rising: The Fall of the Soviets and the Challenge of Independence, Nadia Diuk, Adrian Karatnycky</ref>
=== Clash === The Soviet detachment, armed with military batons and [[Entrenching tool|spades]] (a favorite weapon of [[spetsnaz|Soviet special forces]] <ref>[[Viktor Suvorov]] ''[http://militera.lib.ru/research/suvorov6/index.html Spetsnaz]'', 1987, Hamish Hamilton Ltd, {{ISBN|0-241-11961-8}}</ref>), advanced on demonstrators moving along the [[Rustaveli Avenue]].<ref name=Sobchak /> During the advance, the soldiers started to attack demonstrators with spades, inflicting injuries both minor and serious to anyone who was struck.<ref name="ReferenceA" />
One of the victims of the attack was a 16-year-old girl who tried to get away from the advancing soldiers, but was chased down and beaten to death near the steps of the government building, receiving blows to the head and chest. She was dragged out of the area by her mother who was also attacked and wounded. This particularly violent attack was recorded on video from the balcony of a building located on the other side of the avenue. The video was used in the aftermath as evidence during [[Anatoly Sobchak|Sobchak's]] ''Parliamentary commission on investigation of events of April 9, 1989''. Groups of Soviet soldiers were reported to chase individual victims, rather than dispersing the crowd.<ref>{{YouTube|id=LToXsIwZ_P8|title=Documentary Film - The April 9, 1989 Tragedy}}</ref>
The [[stampede]] following the attack resulted in the death of 19 people, among them 17 women. [[Autopsies]] conducted on the victims concluded the direct cause of death of all those who died, with the exception of one case of serious skull and brain injury, was suffocation (asphyxia) caused by both the compression of the body and the inhalation of chemical substances.<ref name="Sobchak" />
Official Soviet reports blamed the demonstrators for causing the clash, saying that the troops were attacked with sticks and knives.<ref name="lib.unb.ca">http://www.lib.unb.ca/Texts/JCS/bin/get4.cgi?directory=spring99/&filename=cotter_notes.htm</ref> According to Tass, the soldiers followed orders not to use their weapons, but that extremists attacked them with pieces of metal, bricks and sticks. Tass described the demonstrators as stirring interethnic strife and calling for the overthrow of the Georgian government. President Gorbachev slammed "actions by irresponsible persons" for loss of life. He said that the disturbances sought to overthrow the Georgian government and stir ethnic tension in Georgia. Foreign ministry spokesman said that the clashes were sparked by "die-hard nationalists, extremists and political adventurists who are abusing democratization to the detriment of our new policy of openness and of our very society." <ref>Associated Press, Toronto Star, Apr 13, 1989</ref><ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1989-04-11/news/mn-1600_1_calm-soviet-georgia-nationalist-armenia-and-azerbaijan Los Angeles Times, April 11, 1989]</ref>
[[CN gas|CN]] and [[CS gas]] were used against the demonstrators;<ref name="Sobchak" /> vomiting, respiratory problems and sudden paralyses of the [[nervous system]] were reported.<ref name="State 1998 pp. 26-27">Nationalist Violence and the State: Political Authority and Contentious Repertoires in the Former USSR, Mark R. Beissinger Comparative Politics, Vol. 30, No. 4 (Jul., 1998), pp. 26-27.</ref>
The unarmed police officers attempted to evacuate the panicked group of demonstrators, however a video taken secretly by opposition journalists showed that soldiers did not allow doctors and emergency workers to help the injured people; even ambulances were attacked by the advancing soldiers<ref>Defending the Border: Identity, Religion, And Modernity in the Republic of Georgia (Culture and Society After Socialism) , Mathijs Pelkmans pp. 127-39</ref> Captured on film, the image of a young man beating a tank with a stick became a symbol of the Georgian anti-Soviet movement.<ref name="Georgia p 18">Georgia: In the Mountains of Poetry, Peter Nasmyth, p 18</ref>
On April 10, the Soviet government issued a statement blaming the demonstrators for causing unrest and danger to the safety of the public. The next day, Georgian TV showed the bodies of the 19 women violently killed, demonstrating alleged brutality by the Soviet soldiers, as the faces of the deceased women were hard to identify due to the facial injuries and blows to the head. The Soviet government blamed the demonstrators for the death of the 20 people, claiming that they had trampled each other while panicking and retreating from the advancing Soviet soldiers.<ref name="Georgia p 18" /> Ironically there was some truth in this, as Soviet troops had blocked all exists from the area except for one narrow passage, which made flight from the area difficult and induced the crush of the crowd and, possibly, some desperate defensive violence by the trapped demonstrators.<ref>Lehrke, Jesse Paul. The Transition to National Armies in the Former Soviet Republics, 1988-2005.” Oxfordshire, UK: Routledge (2013), Chapter 2. (See: http://www.routledge.com/books/details/9780415688369/) </ref>
A Parliamentary commission on investigation of events of April 9, 1989 in Tbilisi was launched by [[Anatoly Sobchak]], member of [[Congress of People's Deputies of the Soviet Union|Congress of People's Deputies]] of [[Soviet Union]]. After full investigation and inquiries, the commission confirmed the government's claim that the deaths had resulted from trampling, but another contributing factor had been the chemical substances used against the demonstrators. It condemned the military, which had caused the deaths by trying to disperse demonstrators. The commission's report made it more difficult to use military power against demonstrations of civil unrest in the Soviet Union. Sobchak's report presented a detailed account of the violence which was used against the demonstrators and recommended the full prosecution of military personnel responsible for the April 9 event.<ref name="State 1998 pp. 26-27" />
==Aftermath== {{unreferenced section|date=April 2011}} [[File:April9victims.jpg|250px|thumb|right|Photos of the April 9, 1989 Massacre victims (mostly young women) on a billboard in Tbilisi.]] On April 10, in protest against the crackdown, Tbilisi and the rest of Georgia went out on strike and a 40-day period of mourning was declared. People brought massive collections of flowers to the place of the killings. A state of emergency was declared, but demonstrations continued.
The government of the Georgian SSR resigned as a result of the event. [[Moscow]] claimed the demonstrators attacked first and the soldiers had to repel them. At the first [[Congress of People's Deputies of the Soviet Union|Congress of People's Deputies]] (May–June 1989) [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] disclaimed all responsibility, shifting blame onto the army. The revelations in the liberal Soviet media, as well as the findings of the "pro-[[Perestroika]]" Deputy [[Anatoly Sobchak]]'s commission of enquiry into the Tbilisi events, reported at the second Congress in December 1989, resulted in embarrassment for the Soviet hardliners and army leadership implicated in the event.
==Legacy==
The April 9 tragedy radicalised Georgian opposition to Soviet power. A few months later, a session of the Supreme Council of Georgian SSR, held on November 17–18, 1989, officially condemned the occupation{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} and annexation of [[Democratic Republic of Georgia]] by [[Russian SFSR|Soviet Russia]] in 1921.
The events of April 9 also gave rise to the so-called 'Tbilisi Syndrome'. This syndrome was characterized by the reluctance of military officers and soldiers to take any tactical decisions or even obey orders without a clear trail of responsibility to a higher authority. It arose because of the Soviet leadership's refusal to take responsibility for the orders to clear the square and the commission report's and Shevardnadze's criticism of the military in general. 'Tbilisi Syndrome' continued to spread in the coming years, especially following events in Baku and Vilnius, and contributed in 1991 to the refusal of soldiers to prevent demonstrations during the August 1991 putsch.<ref>Lehrke, Jesse Paul. The Transition to National Armies in the Former Soviet Republics, 1988-2005.” Oxfordshire, UK: Routledge (2013), Chapter 2 and 3.</ref>
On March 31, 1991, Georgians voted overwhelmingly in favor of independence from the [[Soviet Union]] in a [[Georgian independence referendum, 1991|referendum]]. With a 90.5% turnout, approximately 99% voted in favor of independence. On April 9, the second anniversary of the tragedy, the [[Supreme Council of the Republic of Georgia]] proclaimed Georgian sovereignty and independence from the Soviet Union.
A memorial to the victims of the tragedy was opened at the location of the crackdown on [[Rustaveli Avenue]] on November 23, 2004.
==See also== *[[Black January]] *[[Revolutions of 1989]] *[[9 March 1956 massacre in Tbilisi]] *[[1978 Georgian demonstrations]] *[[January Events]] *[[Jeltoqsan]] *[[Novocherkassk massacre]]

'''BlueSky Fiji''' is an annual international R18 music festival held in [[Fiji]].<ref>{{cite web|work =New Zealand Herald|title =Fiji: All Crew Report to the Dancefloor|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/travel/news/article.cfm?c_id=7&objectid=10840915}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =NBR|title =BlueSky Party, Sonaisali Resort Fiji|url=https://www.nbr.co.nz/bluesky-party-sonaisali-resort-fiji}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =New Zealand Herald|title =PM's son among Kiwi partygoers forced off Beachcomber Island by blaze|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11552879i}}</ref> Bluesky Fiji was founded in 2012 and is known for pioneering international music festivals in [[Fiji]].<ref>{{cite web|work =Generator|title =Generator at BlueSky Fiji|url=http://www.generatornz.com/2012/10/generator-at-bluesky/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =NZ Businesses|title =SPRINGBREAK FIJI (USA) LIMITED|url=https://www.nzlbusiness.com/company/registered/Springbreak-Fiji-Usa-Limited}}</ref> The festival has helped establish other international music festivals in Fiji including [[Spring Break Fiji]].<ref>{{cite web|work =Crave |title =Spring Break 2016: You’re Going To Fiji Next Year |url=http://www.craveonline.com/culture/882413-spring-break-2016-fiji}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work = Stuff |title =What on earth is Spring Break? |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/travel/news/74753411/What-on-earth-is-Spring-Break}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =EDM Tunes|title =Party On a Private Tropical Island with Spring Break Fiji|url=http://www.edmtunes.com/2015/06/party-private-tropical-island-spring-break-fiji/}}</ref>
==History== BlueSky Fiji was established in 2012 by Tourism HQ. It originally took place at Sonaisali Island Resort, but in 2015 the festival moved to [[Mana Island, Fiji]].<ref>{{cite web|work =SUR|title =Bluesky Fiji |url=http://sur.ly/i/blueskyfiji.com/}}</ref>
==Lineups== ===2012=== (October 5th to 8th, Sonaisali Island) * Tiki Taane, Dick Johnson, State of Mind, Dan Aux, Sam Hill, Tim Phin, MayaVanya, Nick D, Dean Campbell, Thane Kirby, Kara Rickard, Bulletproof, General Lee, Murry Sweetpants, Peter Urlich, and Karn Hall.
===2013=== (November 16th to 19th, Sonaisali Island) * Tiki Taane, Peacekeepers aka Sambora and P-Digsss, Peking Duk, Tom Piper, Motez, Danny T, [[LDRU]], Yahtzel, Dan Aux, Ember, General Lee, Karn Hall, Daniel Farley, Aroha, Thane Kirby, Benson, Mike Metro, Bevan Keys, Beat Mafia, Cam Robertson, and MurrySweetpants.
===2014=== (October 24th to 27th, Sonaisali Island) * P-Money, Tali P Digsss, Dick Johnson, Clarke Gayford, Aroha, Dan Aux, Tim Phin, Karn Hall, Sam Hill, Thane Kirby, and Sweetpants.
===2015=== (November 8th to 11th, Mana Island) * P-Money, Ladi6, Tiki Taane, P Digsss, Thane Kirby, Laughton Kora, Dick Johnson, Peter Urlich, Aroha and Tali, Dan Aux, Tim Phin, Karn Hall, Mike Ross, Sam Hill and Hamish Crocker, General Lee, Mayavanya, MurrySweetpants, Zeisha Fremaux, Knox (Fiji) and Billy & The Kids (Fiji)
===2016=== (November 6th to 9th, Mana Island) * P-Money, Tiki Taane, Hollie Smith, P Digsss, Laughton Kora, Knox (Fiji), Aroha, Tali, Kings, Dick Johnson, Tim Phin, Karn Hall, Dj Lucas, General Lee, Thane Kirby, Tim Lambourne, Eastern Bloc, Logg Cabin, Chiccoreli, Hamish Crocker, Sam Hill, Sweetpants and Billy & The Kids (Fiji).
==See also== *[[List of festivals in Fiji]] *[[George FM]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

{{Underlinked|date=June 2016}}
{{Infobox company | name = | logo = | type = | predecessor = | successor = | founder = Gregory Lamberson, Chris Scioli | defunct = | fate = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = film-exhibition | genre = | products = | production = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | footnotes = | intl = | foundation = 2013 | location_city = [[Buffalo, New York]] | location_country = United States of America | location = | locations = | homepage = [http://www.buffalodreamsfantasticfilmfestival.com/ Buffalo Dreams Fantastic Film Festival] }}
'''Buffalo Dreams Fantastic Film Festival''' was founded by Chris Scioli and by award-winning author and filmmaker [[Gregory Lamberson]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://morbidlybeautiful.com/interview-gregory-lamberson/ |website=Morbidly Beautiful}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://horrorfuel.com/2017/05/28/greg-lamberson-discusses-johnny-gruesome-film-festival-interview/ |website=Horror Fuel}}</ref> The festival is a ten-day celebration<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pophorror.com/interview-greg-lamberson/ |website=Pop Horror}}</ref> which showcase various films from around the world.<ref>{{cite web |title=Falls residents on the big screen at Buffalo film festival |url=http://www.niagara-gazette.com/news/night_and_day/falls-residents-on-the-big-screen-at-buffalo-film-festival/article_31a487fa-8491-11e5-838d-17cacfd2e3aa.html |website=Niagara Gazette}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=RECOGNIZED AND BRANDED, COLLEGE CAMPUSES ARE INTHRALLED WITH THE BUFFALO DREAMS FANTASTIC FILM FESTIVAL |url=http://thefilmfestivalhome.com/recognized-and-branded-college-campuses-are-inthralled-with-the-buffalo-dreams-fantastic-film-festival/ |website=Film Festival Home}}</ref>
The mission of the festival is to screen, "bold, original and edgy films that are well made"<ref>{{cite web |title=Buffalo Dreams About Page |url=http://www.buffalodreamsfantasticfilmfestival.com/about-us/about-the-festival/}}</ref> and to help year-round with providing a platform for Western, NY filmmakers to screen their work.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Best of Buffalo Dreams Comes to The Screening Room |url=https://diaboliquemagazine.com/best-buffalo-dreams-comes-screening-room/ |website=Diabolique Magazine}}</ref> In addition to a full feature schedule, the festival is known for its shorts blocks.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://buffalonews.com/2015/11/04/short-films-at-buffalo-dreams-are-long-on-entertainment/ |website=Buffalo News}}</ref>
== Notable Guests ==
The festival often partners with [[Lloyd Kaufman]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Buffalo Dreams Film Fest Hosting NY Premiere of Return to Return to Nuke ‘Em High aka Vol. 2 |url=https://www.dreadcentral.com/news/246601/buffalo-dreams-film-fest-hosting-ny-premiere-return-return-nuke-em-high-aka-vol-2/ |website=Dread Central}}</ref> and [[Troma]] to show early screenings of Troma films.<ref>{{cite web |title=Buffalo Dreams To Host Screening of Troma’s Return to Nuke ‘Em High |url=http://www.youwoncannes.com/2013/10/11/buffalo-dreams-host-preview-tromas-return-nuke-em-high/ |website=You Won Cannes}}</ref>
Screenwriter and film producer [[Roy Frumkes]] judged the unproduced original screenplay competition for the 2016 season.<ref>{{cite web |title=Roy Frumkes Screens STREET TRASH At Buffalo Dreams For 30th Anniversary |url=https://www.horrorsociety.com/2016/09/26/roy-frumkes-screens-street-trash-buffalo-dreams-30th-anniversary/ |website=Horror Society}}</ref>
== Awards == The festival gives out awards in a number of categories including special Dreamer Awards, Filmmaker of the Year Awards, Living Legend Awards, and the [[Lois Weber]] Award, designed to recognize the achievements of contemporary female filmmakers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.buffalodreamsfantasticfilmfestival.com/press-news/ |website=Buffalo Dreams Awards Page}}</ref>
The 2017 special award winners were Adrian Esposito (Filmmaker of the Year), Devi Snively (Lois Weber Award), [[Fred Olen Ray]] (Living Legend Award), Jon Keeyes (Dedication to Excellence in Filmmaking), and Christopher Olen Ray (Indie Genre Spirit Award).<ref>{{cite web |title=Buffalo Dreams 2017 Dreamer Awards |url=http://www.buffalodreamsfantasticfilmfestival.com/2017-dreamer-award-winners/}}</ref> The 2018 special award winners were [[Brett Kelly (director)|Brett Kelly]] (Filmmaker of the Year), [[Sophia Cacciola]] (Lois Weber Award), [[Michael J. Epstein]] (Dedication to Excellence in Independent Filmmaking), and Sam Qualiana (Indie Genre Spirit Award).<ref>{{cite web |title=Buffalo Dreams Fantastic Film Festival schedule announced |url=https://bloody-flicks.co.uk/2018/10/31/buffalo-dreams-fantastic-film-festival-schedule-announced/ |website=Bloody Flicks}}</ref>
== Notable films featured == The Incident (2015)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.buffalorising.com/2015/10/3rd-annual-buffalo-dreams-fantastic-film-festival-to-screen-31-wny-films/ |website=Buffalo Rising}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Interview: Mexican genre filmmaker Isaac Ezban |url=http://www.dailypublic.com/articles/11042015/interview-mexican-genre-filmmaker-isaac-ezban |website=Daily Public}}</ref>
[[Blood of the Tribades]] (2016)
Let Her Out (2016)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://411mania.com/movies/the-buffalo-dreams-fantastic-film-festival-2016-report/ |website=411 Mania}}</ref>
Night of the Virgin (2016)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailypublic.com/articles/11022016/buffalo-dreams-fantastic-film-festival-preview |website=Daily Public}}</ref>
Tonight She Comes (2016)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://411mania.com/movies/the-buffalo-dreams-fantastic-film-festival-2016-report/ |website=411 Mania}}</ref>
Post Apocalyptic Commando Shark (2018)<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ruberto |first1=Toni |title=100 films: Buffalo Dreams Fantastic Film Festival returns |url=https://buffalonews.com/2018/11/01/100-films-buffalo-dreams-fantastic-film-festival-returns/ |website=Buffalo News}}</ref>
I Dare You to Open Your Eyes (2018)<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ruberto |first1=Toni |title=100 films: Buffalo Dreams Fantastic Film Festival returns |url=https://buffalonews.com/2018/11/01/100-films-buffalo-dreams-fantastic-film-festival-returns/ |website=Buffalo News}}</ref>
Johnny Gruesome (2018)<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ruberto |first1=Toni |title=100 films: Buffalo Dreams Fantastic Film Festival returns |url=https://buffalonews.com/2018/11/01/100-films-buffalo-dreams-fantastic-film-festival-returns/ |website=Buffalo News}}</ref>
[[Clickbait (film)|Clickbait]] (2018)<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ruberto |first1=Toni |title=100 films: Buffalo Dreams Fantastic Film Festival returns |url=https://buffalonews.com/2018/11/01/100-films-buffalo-dreams-fantastic-film-festival-returns/ |website=Buffalo News}}</ref>
Derelicts (2018)<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ruberto |first1=Toni |title=100 films: Buffalo Dreams Fantastic Film Festival returns |url=https://buffalonews.com/2018/11/01/100-films-buffalo-dreams-fantastic-film-festival-returns/ |website=Buffalo News}}</ref>
Tommy Battles the Silver Sea Dragon (2018)<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ruberto |first1=Toni |title=100 films: Buffalo Dreams Fantastic Film Festival returns |url=https://buffalonews.com/2018/11/01/100-films-buffalo-dreams-fantastic-film-festival-returns/ |website=Buffalo News}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.buffalodreamsfantasticfilmfestival.com/ Buffalo Dreams Fantastic Film Festival] website
