page.title: International Hot-Air Balloon Festival in Château-d'Oex
Invitations to the first inauguration of Barack Obama

revision.text:
[[File:Inaugural invitation 2009.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Photograph of the invitation to Barack Obama's inauguration]] One million '''invitations to Barack Obama's inauguration''' were sent out in the first week of January 2009. Printed between December 11, 2008, and January 2, 2009, the invitations invited people to celebrate [[Barack Obama]]'s [[First inauguration of Barack Obama|inauguration]] as the [[List of Presidents of the United States|forty-fourth]] [[President of the United States]]. The invitations have kept the same basic design of a gold seal and black script since the 1949 inauguration of [[Harry S. Truman]], but this invitation was produced in a [[Environmentally friendly|green]] manner, using recycled paper, by companies certified by the [[Forest Stewardship Council]] (FSC).
==Preparations== ===Design=== The invitations have followed the same design since those for [[Harry S. Truman]]'s [[Harry S. Truman 1949 presidential inauguration|presidential inauguration]] on January 20, 1949.<ref name="SI">{{cite news |first=Stephannia |last=Cleaton |title=Staten Island firm to send out Obama's invitations |url=http://www.silive.com/news/index.ssf/2009/01/staten_island_firm_to_send_out.html |work=[[Staten Island Advance]] |date=January 1, 2009 |accessdate=January 21, 2009 }}</ref><ref name="ABC">{{cite news |first=David |last=Muir |title=Printer Crafts 1 Million Inaugural Invitations |url=http://abcnews.go.com/WN/Inauguration/story?id=6551979&page=1 |format=video |publisher=[[World News with Charles Gibson|ABC World News with Charles Gibson]] |date=December 30, 2009 |accessdate=January 21, 2009 }}</ref> The invitations have a gold embossed inauguration seal at the top of the page and black-inked script using customized Shelley Alegro and Kuenstler typefaces.<ref name="NYT">{{cite news |first=Caroline |last=Dworin |title=Inside a Gritty Brooklyn Factory, Potomac Fever |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/21/nyregion/thecity/21prin.html?_r=1&partner=permalink&exprod=permalink |work=[[New York Times]] |page=CY5 |date=December 21, 2008 |accessdate=January 21, 2009 }}</ref> The invitation reads, "The [[Presidential Inaugural Committee]] requests the honor of your presence to attend and participate in the Inauguration of Barack H. Obama as President of the United States of America and Joseph R. Biden Jr. as Vice President of the United States of America on Tuesday, the twentieth of January two thousand and nine in the city of Washington."<ref name="SI" />
===Printing=== [[File:Reverse of seal of Obama inauguration invitation.jpg|right|thumb|150px|The reverse of the seal of Obama's inauguration invitation]] Ink for the invitations was supplied by [[Chicago]] company BuzzInk,<ref name="NYT" /> and the [[Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies]] selected Precise Continental of [[Brooklyn, New York]] to print the invitations.<ref name="NYT" /> Precise Continental was selected because it is a [[trade union|union company]], uses recycled paper, and is [[Forest Stewardship Council]] certified.<ref name="NYT" /> The printing technique for the invitations was [[engraving]]. The design was cut into the surface of a copper plate, which was then inked and inserted into a printing press with a sheet of paper. The result is a slightly raised impression on the front of the page and a slightly indented impression on the bottom.<ref name="HOW">{{cite news |url=http://www.howdesign.com/article/inaugurationinvitation/ |title=1M Inaugural Invites for Obama Stirs the Ink at Printer |accessdate=January 21, 2009 |last=Kuhn |first=Jessica |date=January 16, 2009 |work=[[HOW (magazine)|HOW]] |publisher=[[F+W Media Inc.|F+W Media]] }}</ref> The first plate had to be scrapped because it was engraved without the President's middle initial.<ref>{{cite news |title=Obama Inauguration: Local Company Printing Invitations |url=http://www.myfoxny.com/myfox/pages/News/Detail?contentId=8204279&version=1&locale=EN-US&layoutCode=VSTY&pageId=3.2.1 |publisher=[[WNYW]] |format=video |location= |id= |pages= |page= |date= |accessdate=21 January 2009 |language= |quote= }}</ref> The golden seal was engraved in three printing runs. The first print laid down a rough-textured basic gold shape. The second run added smoothness and shine, and the final print run added the fine details to the seal.<ref name="HOW" /> One million invitations were printed over 20 hours every day between December 11, 2008, and January 2, 2009, with employees working in two shifts and taking breaks only on Christmas Day and New Year's Day.<ref name="NYT" /><ref name="HOW" /> The invitations were printed one at a time on 11×17 sheets of paper, which were then cut in half to 8½×11 sheets.<ref name="ABC" /><ref name="HOW" />
===Paper=== The paper used to print the invitations on initially came from [[Michigan]]. Waste paper collected from local companies in [[Grand Rapids]] was collected by [http://www.padnos.com/ Louis Padnos Iron & Metal]. It was shipped to Wisconsin, where it was turned into [[Pulp (paper)|pulp]].<ref>{{cite news |title=West Michigan scraps part of inaugural invitations |url=http://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2009/01/west_michigan_scraps_part_of_i.html |work=[[Grand Rapids Press]] |date=January 20, 2009 |accessdate=January 21, 2009 }}</ref> The Whiting Paper Mill, owned by Neenah Paper, another FSC certified company, converted the pulp into ''CLASSIC CREST Recycled 100 Natural White Papers manufactured by Neenah Paper'', which contains FSC certified fibers and is made with 100 percent renewable green energy in a completely carbon-neutral, chlorine-free process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neenahpaper.com/CLASSICCRESTColorChart/index.asp?ft=Home |title=Classic Crest Color Chart |accessdate=January 21, 2009 |publisher=[[Neeneh Papers]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081222013843/http://www.neenahpaper.com/CLASSICCRESTcolorChart/index.asp?ft=Home |archivedate=December 22, 2008 }}</ref> The paper was delivered to Precise by [[Central National-Gottesman]], another FSC certified company.<ref>{{cite press release |title=Obama team chooses FSC-certified paper for inaugural invitations |publisher=[[Forest Stewardship Council]] |url=http://www.fscus.org/news/?article=533 |accessdate=January 21, 2009 }}</ref>
===Mailing=== Prompt Mailers of [[Staten Island, New York]] mailed the invitations, which also included a letter from the Presidential Inaugural Committee and a leaflet from the inaugural store. Between December 31, 2008, and January 7, 2009, 3,100 to 3,500 envelopes were filled and sealed every hour.<ref name="SI" />
==Recipients== [[File:JCCIC-2009 Inaugural Map.JPG|thumb|250px|Color-coded assigned entrances and seating areas are noted in official map from the Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies.]] Invitations were sent to the chiefs of diplomatic missions to the United States and their spouses but not to any other representatives of foreign countries. As a result, [[North Korea]]'s offer to send a senior envoy was rejected.<ref>{{cite news |title=N Korea "sought Obama invite" |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia-pacific/2009/01/20091135623421404.html |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=2009-01-13 |accessdate=2009-01-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090121101135/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia-pacific/2009/01/20091135623421404.html |archivedate=2009-01-21 |df= }}</ref> The [[Tuskegee Airmen]] were among the invited guests for the inauguration.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/10/us/politics/10inaug.html|title=Inauguration Is a Culmination for Black Airmen |accessdate=2008-12-19|date=2008-12-09|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Seelye, Katharine Q.}}</ref> The five-person crew of [[US Airways Flight 1549]], including pilot [[Chesley Sullenberger]], were also invited.<ref>{{cite news |first=Katharine Q. |last=Seelye |title=Obama Invites Flight 1549 Pilot and Crew to Inauguration |url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/01/19/obama-invites-flight-1549-pilot-and-crew-to-inauguration/?hp |publisher=The New York Times |date=2009-01-19 |accessdate=2009-01-19}}</ref> Entertainment industry figures such as [[Beyoncé]], [[Jay-Z]], [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Magic Johnson]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Muhammad Ali]], [[John Cusack]], and [[Oprah Winfrey]] received invitations,<ref name="Insider">{{cite news |title=Celeb Sightings at the Inauguration |url=http://www.theinsider.com/news/1560108_Celeb_Sightings_at_the_Inauguration?ttag=cbsnti&imageHeight=52&imageWidth=52 |work=[[The Insider (TV series)|The Insider]] |date=January 20, 2009 |accessdate=January 21, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Barack Assumes Presidency as the World Watches |url=http://www.etonline.com/news/2009/01/69866/index.html |work=[[Entertainment Tonight]] |date=January 20, 2009 |accessdate=January 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090124043759/http://www.etonline.com/news/2009/01/69866/index.html |archivedate=January 24, 2009 }}</ref> as well as politicians such as [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]], Governor of California; Massachusetts Senator [[Ted Kennedy]]; and Arizona Senator [[John McCain]].<ref name="Insider" /> The invitiation to Evangelical pastor [[Rick Warren]] drew some criticism.<ref>{{cite news |title=Warren defends invite by Obama |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2008/dec/22/warren-defends-invite-by-obama/ |agency=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[Washington Times]] |date=December 22, 2008 |accessdate=January 21, 2009 }}</ref>
Eighty-seven-year-old [[Sarah Onyango Obama|Sarah Obama]] led a group of Obama's [[Kenya]]n relatives from his father's home village of [[Kogelo]].<ref name=washingtontimes> {{cite news |first=|last=|title= Embassy Row: Obama's Grandma|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/jan/07/embassy-row-54767307/ |work= [[Washington Times]] |publisher= |date=2009-01-07 |accessdate=2009-01-19}}</ref> Other relatives traveling to Washington from Kenya as guests included Obama's aunt Maggie Obama and an uncle, [[Said Obama]].<ref name=washingtontimes/><ref name=iol> {{cite news |first=|last=|title= Obama's gran brings traditional gifts|url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=3&art_id=vn20090118075407893C127411 |work= [[Independent Online (South Africa)]] |publisher=[[Independent News & Media]] |date=2009-01-18 |accessdate=2009-01-19}}</ref>
Members of the general public also received invitations to the inaugural ceremony. Invitations were sent to constituents, who received one of the 240,000 color-coded tickets to the inaugural ceremony distributed by [[United States House of Representatives|House]] and [[United States Senate|Senate]] congressional members of the [[111th United States Congress|111th U.S. Congress]].<ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Congress-to-Distribute-Inaugural-Tickets-Starting-Monday.html|title=Congress to receive inaugural tickets today|date=2009-01-13|publisher=[[WRC-TV]] (Washington, DC)|accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/01/12/tickets-obama-inauguration-create-stir-capitol-hill|title=Tickets to Obama inauguration create stir on Capitol Hill|author=Pergram, C.|date=2009-01-12|publisher=[[Fox News Channel|Fox News]]|accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://inaugural.senate.gov/index.cfm Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090430011059/http://www.pic2009.org/content/home/ Presidential Inauguration Committee] * [http://www.neenahpaper.com Neenah Paper] * [http://www.cng-inc.com/ Central National-Gottesman] * [http://www.precisecorp.com/ Precise Continental]
{{Barack Obama}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Obama, Barack}} [[Category:First inauguration of Barack Obama]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=February 2017}} {{cleanup list|date=September 2017}} European Classical music has long relied on [[music competitions]] to provide a public forum that identifies the strongest players and contributes to the establishment of their professional careers. This is a list of current [[competition]]s in [[European classical music|classical music]], with each competition and reference link given only once. Many offer competitions across a range of categories and in these cases they are listed under "General/mixed". Competitions with age restrictions are listed under "Young musicians". == Chamber music == [[File:Roman Kramsztyk Koncert 1918.jpg|thumb|Roman Kramsztyk ''Koncert'' (1918)]] * Chesapeake Chamber Music Competition (Maryland, USA)[http://www.chesapeakechambermusic.org/competition/index.htm Chesapeake Chamber Music Competition] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150321095734/http://www.chesapeakechambermusic.org/competition/index.htm |date=March 21, 2015 }} *[https://www.classicpurevienna.com Classic Pure Vienna International Music Competitions] (Vienna, Austria) * Duo Entendre Composition Competition for French horn and piano (Newcastle, Australia)[http://duoentendre.com/competition Duo Entendre Composition Competition] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006072144/http://duoentendre.com/competition |date=October 6, 2013 }} * Henri Tomasi International Woodwind Quintet Competition (Marseille, France) * International Chamber Music Competition Città di Pinerolo e Torino Città metropolitana (Pinerolo, Italy) * [[International Chamber Music Competition Hamburg]] for piano trios and string quartets (Hamburg, Germany)[http://www.icmc-hamburg.de/ International Chamber Music Competition] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081223101443/http://www.icmc-hamburg.de/ |date=2008-12-23 }} * International Chamber Music Ensemble Competition of New England (Boston, MA){{Cite web|url=http://cmfone.org|title=Chamber Music Foundation and Competition|website=cmfone.org|access-date=2017-06-25}} * International Contest–Festival of Chamber Ensemble Performance (Magnitogorsk, Russia){{cite web|url=http://www.magkmusic.com/competitions/1007-the-4th-international-contest-festival-of-chamber-ensemble-performance-named-after-t-a-gaidamovich.html|title=Магнитогорская государственная консерватория - The 4th International Contest – Festival of Chamber Ensemble Performance named after T. A. Gaidamovich|first=Сидоров|last=Антон|publisher=}} * International Maria Yudina Competition of Young Pianists, Duo Pianists and Chamber Ensembles (St. Petersburg, Russia){{Cite web|url=http://www.imfrt.ru/?page_id=1190&lang=en|title=NOMINATIONS « МУЗЫКАЛЬНЫЕ КОНКУРСЫ|website=www.imfrt.ru|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-25}} * International Radio Competition for Young Musicians Concertino Praga (Prague, Czech Republic){{cite web|url=http://www.rozhlas.cz/concertino/portal/|title=Concertino Praga|publisher=}} * [[International Shostakovich Chamber Music Competition]] (Moscow, Russia){{Cite web|url=http://www.ippolitovka.ru/node/1933|title=II Международный Конкурс Камерных Ансамблей {{!}} Государственный музыкально-педагогический институт имени М.М. Ипполитова-Иванова|website=www.ippolitovka.ru|access-date=2017-06-25}} * International String Quartet Competition [[Radom Chamber Orchestra]] (Radom, Poland){{cite web|url=http://www.rok.art.pl/|title=Radomska Orkiestra Kameralna|first=Agencja interaktywna Click Media - www.clickmedia.pl,|last=www.pozycjonowanie.radom.pl|publisher=}} * Melbourne International Chamber Music Competition (previously named the Asia-Pacific Chamber Music Competition) for piano trios and string quartets (Melbourne, Australia){{cite web|url=https://musicaviva.com.au/comp/|title= Melbourne International Chamber Music Competition|publisher=}} * ON STAGE International Classical Music Competition (Online Competition){{cite web|url=http://www.onstagecompetition.com/|title=ON STAGE|website=On Stage Classical Music Competition}} * Plovdiv International Chamber Music Competition (Plovdiv, Bulgaria){{cite web|url=http://www.plovdivchambercompetition.org|title=Home|website=PLOVDIV INTERNATIONAL CHAMBER MUSIC COMPETITION}} * Premio Paolo Borciani, International String Quartet Competition (Reggio Emilia, Italy){{cite web|url=http://www.premioborciani.org/|title=Premio Borciani – News e Curiosità dal mondo del gioco d'azzardo….|publisher=}} * Quebec Music Competition (Montreal, Quebec, Canada) Live and Online{{cite web|url=http://www.quebecmusiccompetition.com/competition.html?lang=en|title=Quebec Canadian Music Competition - an encouraging Canadian Music Competition in Quebec for all ages and levels|website=Quebec Music Competition - National and International Music Competition for all ages and levels}} * St Martin's Chamber Music Competition (London, UK){{cite web|url=http://www.smitf.org/page/music/competition.html|title=Chamber Music Competition - St Martin-in-the-Fields - Trafalgar Square, concerts in London|publisher=}} * "Salieri - Zinetti" International Chamber Music Competition (Verona/ Mantova, Italy){{cite web|url=http://www.salieri-zinetticompetition.eu/|title="Salieri - Zinetti" International Chamber Music Competition|publisher=}} * Sydney Eisteddfod Musica Viva Chamber Music Award (Sydney, Australia){{cite web|url=http://www.sydneyeisteddfod.com.au/|title=Sydney Eisteddfod|publisher=}} * Terem Crossover International Music Competition instrumental ensembles (Saint-Petersburg, Russia){{cite web|url=http://www.terem.cc/|title=Главная. Terem Crossover|first=|last=AlkoDesign.Ru|publisher=}} * Trondheim International Chamber Music Competition (Trondheim, Norway){{cite web|url=http://www.ticc.no/|title=TRONDHEIM INTL CHAMBER MUSIC COMPETITION|publisher=}} * Triomphe de l'Art International Music Competition (Brussels, Belgium) == Choral/voice == * [https://www.nuovocanto.org Nuovo Canto Opera Competition in Milano] * The Featured NY. International Singing Competition (New York, USA){{cite web|url=https://www.featuredsingingcompetition.com/|title=The Featured NY. International Singing Competition |publisher=}} * Vancouver International Music Competition (Vancouver, Canada){{cite web|url=http://www.vancouvercompetition.com/|title=VANCOUVER INTERNATIONAL MUSIC COMPETITION|publisher=}} * International Early Music Vocal Competition "Canticum Gaudium", Poznan, Poland{{cite web|url=http://www.poznanfestival.pl|title=International Early Music Vocal Competition "Canticum Gaudium}} [[File:Candlelight Master Young Boy Singing.jpg|thumb|Candlelight Master
''Young Boy Singing'' (1650)]] * American Protege International Vocal Competition (USA){{cite web|url=http://www.americanprotege.com/vocal/|title=Top Voice Competition and Song Contest - American Protégé|publisher=}} * Australian Concerto and Vocal Competition (Townsville, Australia){{cite web|url= http://acvc.com.au|title=Australian Concerto and Vocal Competition=}} * Barry Alexander International Vocal Competition (USA){{cite web|url=http://www.alexanderbuono.com/voice-competition.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141017093039/http://www.alexanderbuono.com/voice-competition.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2014-10-17|title=Barry Alexander International Vocal Competition|publisher=}} * [[BBC Singer of the World competition]] (Cardiff, Wales){{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b007qn4b|title=BBC Cardiff Singer of the World|publisher=}} * [[Boris Christoff]] International Competition for Young Singers (Sofia, Bulgaria){{cite web|url=http://www.borischristoff.dir.bg/|title=Boris Christoff|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304070352/http://www.borischristoff.dir.bg/|archivedate=2016-03-04|df=}} *[https://www.classicpurevienna.com Classic Pure Vienna International Music Competitions] (Vienna, Austria) * Concurs Internacional de cant Jaume Aragall (Barcelona, Spain)[http://www.concursaragall.com/ Concurs Internacional de cant Jaume Aragall] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160219090652/http://www.concursaragall.com/ |date=2016-02-19 }} * Concours international de chant de Toulouse (Toulouse, France) * Concours International Nei Stemmen (Luxemburg City, Luxemburg){{cite web|url=http://neistemmen.com/|title=Nei Stëmmen - Elevating your opera singer talent|publisher=}} * [[Elena Obraztsova]] International Competition for young opera singers (St. Petersburg, Russia){{cite web|url=http://www.obraztsova.com/home.html|title=home|first=|last=DataPax|publisher=}} * Elizabeth Connell Prize International Singing Competition for Sopranos{{cite web|url=http://www.jsrbfoundation.com/awards-prizes/elizabeth-connell-prize/|title=Elizabeth Connell Prize|publisher=}} * [[European Grand Prix for Choral Singing]] * [[International Johann Sebastian Bach Competition]] (Leipzig, Germany) * International Hans Gabor Belvedere Singing Competition (Vienna, Austria){{cite web|url=http://www.belvedere-competition.com/|title=Belvedere Competition|publisher=}} * International Singing Competition [[Neue Stimmen]] ([[Gütersloh]], [[Germany]]){{cite web|url=https://neue-stimmen.de/en.html|title=International Singing Competition Neue Stimmen|publisher=Bertelsmann Stiftung|access-date=October 27, 2017}} * [[International Stasys Šimkus choir competition]] ([[Klaipėda]], [[Lithuania]]){{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/InternationalStasysSimkusChoirCompetition/ |title= International Stasys Šimkus Choir Competition |publisher=}} * [[International Tchaikovsky Competition]] (Moscow, Russia) * [[International Vocal Competition ´s-Hertogenbosch]] ('s-Hertogenbosch, Netherlands) * International Voice Competition - Gerda Lissner Foundation (New York, USA)[http://www.gerdalissner.org/competition.html/ International Hans Gabor Belvedere Singing Competition] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518194826/http://www.gerdalissner.org/competition.html/ |date=May 18, 2015 }} * [https://www.fibich-competition.cz/ International Zdeněk Fibich Competition in interpretation of melodrama]{{Cite web|url=https://www.fibich-competition.cz|title=International Zdeněk Fibich Competition – Music competition web|website=www.fibich-competition.cz|language=cs-CZ|access-date=2018-04-11}} * Jan, Edward, Józefina Reszke Vocal Competition{{cite web|url=http://www.filharmonia.com.pl/content.php?ContentId=58|title=Filharmonia Częstochowska im. Bronisława Hubermana - 2015|publisher=Filharmonia Częstochowska}} * Joan Sutherland & Richard Bonynge Bel Canto Award{{cite web|url=http://www.jsrbfoundation.com/awards-prizes/bel-canto-award/|title=Bel Canto Award|publisher=}} * The [[Klaudia Taev Competition]] for Young Opera Singers (Pärnu, Estonia). * Lotte Lehman League Art Song Contest{{cite web|url=http://lottelehmannleague.org/|title=Main Landing - Lotte Lehmann League|publisher=}} * The Mirjam Helin International Singing Competition (Helsinki, Finland) * Montserrat Caballe International Singing Competition (Zaragoza, Spain){{cite web|url=http://www.concursocaballe.org/saludo.asp?idioma=ENG/|title=Concurso Internacional de Canto Montserrat Caballé|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303231213/http://www.concursocaballe.org/saludo.asp?idioma=ENG%2F|archivedate=2016-03-03|df=}} * National Anthem Bicentennial (Fort McHenry, USA){{cite web|url=http://www.anthembicentennial.org/|title=200th Anniversary of the Star Spangled Banner - Fort McHenry National Monument and Historic Shrine (U.S. National Park Service)|publisher=}} * [[Operalia, The World Opera Competition]] (Paris, France) * Prague Christmas (Prague, Czech Republic){{cite web|url=http://www.choirs.cz/|title=Koncertní a cestovní agentura CTA - Choirs.cz|publisher=}} * Quebec Music Competition (Montreal, Quebec, Canada) Live and Online * [[Queen Elisabeth Music Competition]] (Brussels, Belgium) * [[Queen Sonja International Music Competition]] (Oslo, Norway) * Triomphe de l'Art International Music Competition (Brussels, Belgium) ==Composition== [[File:Laurent de La Hyre - Allegorical Figure of Music - WGA12312.jpg|thumb|Laurent de La Hyre
''Allegorical Figure of Music'']] * [[Alba Rosa Viëtor]] Composition Competition (Amsterdam, The Netherlands){{cite Poland){{cite web|url=http://gorecki-competition.com/|title=Henryk Mikołaj Górecki International Composers Competition|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130504112422/http://gorecki-competition.com/|archivedate=2013-05-04|df=}} * International [[Antonín Dvořák]] Composition Argentina){{cite web|url=http://islaverdebronces.com.ar/?page_id=663|title=New music for brass|publisher=}} * Kazimierz Serocki International Composers' Competition (Warsaw, Poland){{Cite web |url=https://ptmw.art.pl/2016/11/29/kazimierz-serocki-15th-international-composers-competition-2017/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2017-04-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170423064521/https://ptmw.art.pl/2016/11/29/kazimierz-serocki-15th-international-composers-competition-2017/ |archive-date=2017-04-23 |dead-url=yes |df= }} * Lake George Music Festival Composition Competition (New York,USA) * Midi & MP3 Composition Music Contest for Composers{{cite web|url=http://www.composition-contest.com/|title=Music Composition Contest Online|first=Lavio|last=Pareschi|publisher=}} * Northwest Indiana Symphony Composition Competition (Indiana, USA){{cite web|url=http://www.nisorchestra.org/media/education/Composition%20Competition/2016-17_Composition%20Competition_v2.pdf|title=Northwest Indiana Symphony Composition Competition |publisher=}} * PARMA Student Composer Competition (North Hampton, USA)[http://www.parmarecordings.com/composercompetition PARMA Student Composer Competition] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101065706/http://www.parmarecordings.com/composercompetition |date=January 1, 2014 }} * [[Project Trio]] Composition Competition (Brooklyn, USA){{cite {{Infobox music festival | | music_festival_name = Marktrock | image =Marktrock-oude-markt-leuven-20060813-bjorn-again.jpg | location = [[Leuven]], Belgium | years_active= 1982 - ? | dates = Friday+weekend closest to 15 August | genre = [[Alternative rock]], [[Pop music|Pop]], Dutch | website = {{URL|www.marktrock.com}} }}
'''Marktrock''' is a music festival held each year around 15 August, in the heart of the university town of [[Leuven]], Belgium.<ref>http://www.marktrock.com</ref> There is also a smaller Marktrock festival in [[Poperinge]] which is held the last Saturday of August.
The name Marktrock comes from the Dutch word {{lang|nl|markt}}, meaning market and it is held on 2 squares (4 until 24th edition) in the historical city center of Leuven: "Oude Markt" and "Ladeuzeplein". Until the 24th edition (2006) the three-day festival always had 15 August [[Assumption Day]] as its last day.
In 2004, the 22nd edition of the Marktrock festival was held in Leuven and it has grown into one of Europe's biggest urban music festivals with over 350,000 visitors each year.
On 5 February 2007 the Marktrock vzw organization announced the end of the festival. Main reasons were the raising price of quality artists and groups, the low capacity of the main stage on the "Oude Markt", the new and expensive legal regulations each year, the financial risk of open-air festivals and the organization refused to raise entry tickets for the "Oude Markt" stage again. The rain during the 2006 edition certainly didn't help either. Over the 24 years history of the original MarktRock more than 1400 artists performed at Marktrock, more than 5 million people visited the festival and it launched several Belgian artists.
In March 2007 Marktrock came under new management, which revived the festival and redesigned the 2007 edition. The free stages disappeared, replaced by two paying stages: the Oude Markt focused on local and upcoming bands, while the larger Ladeuzeplein featured established and international artists. This new setup met with significant criticism and attendance was low.
For the 2008 edition, the festival was once again revamped, bringing back the various free stages throughout the city, leaving only the Oude Markt with an entry fee. The festival still struggled to draw the crowds it used to draw.
The 2009 festival changed its approach once more, ditching both the entry fee and international acts. It secured additional funding from the city of Leuven on the condition that the festival would focus on local talent. Despite a line-up of mostly obscure bands, this edition drew an estimated 95,000 visitors, causing minor organisational problems as visitors were turned back from venues that were filled to capacity.

[[File:Tobermory - geograph.org.uk - 401238.jpg|thumb|[[Tobermory, Mull|Tobermory]] on the Isle of Mull is one of the festival's venues ]]
The '''Mendelssohn on Mull Festival''' is an annual chamber music festival held at various venues on the Isles of [[Mull]] and [[Iona]] and the surrounding area, usually during the first week in July. In 2019, the festival dates will move to 1–7 September.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://soundwavesscio.org.uk/mendelssohn-on-mull-festival/ |title=Mendelssohn on Mull Festival 2018 brochure |accessdate=6 July 2018 }}</ref>
==Name==
The festival takes its name from a visit by the composer [[Felix Mendelssohn]] to Scotland in 1829. Although only twenty years old, Mendelssohn was already an established composer and conductor. The natural beauty of Scotland and its rich history of fact and fable delighted the young composer and inspired his [[Symphony No. 3 (Mendelssohn)|Symphony No. 3, ''Scottish'']].<ref>See [http://www.mendelssohninscotland.com/journey-north "The Journey North"] in [http://www.mendelssohninscotland.com/ ''Mendelssohn in Scotland''] website, accessed 9 January 2015.</ref>
Mendelssohn stayed in [[Tobermory, Mull|Tobermory]] on [[Mull]] en route to [[Staffa]] where he visited [[Fingal's Cave]]. The concert overture known both as [[The Hebrides (overture)|''The Hebrides'']] and as ''Fingal's Cave'' was composed shortly after his visit, and was originally entitled 'The Lonely Island'. Mendelssohn sent a postcard to his family with the opening phrase of the overture written on it. In a note to his sister, [[Fanny Mendelssohn]] he said: "In order to make you understand how extraordinarily the Hebrides affected me, I send you the following, which came into my head there."<ref name="OPO">{{cite web|url=http://www.orlandophil.org/downloads/program-notes/2006-07/opo-prog-notes-pac1.pdf |title=Orlando Philharmonic Orchestra Program Notes |accessdate=2006-11-08 |author=David R. Glerum |date=2006-09-30 |format=PDF |pages=4–5 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927205347/http://www.orlandophil.org/downloads/program-notes/2006-07/opo-prog-notes-pac1.pdf |archivedate=September 27, 2007 }}</ref>
The festival that now bears his name was conceived as a musical pilgrimage in commemoration of Mendelssohn's visit.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://soundwavesscio.org.uk/mendelssohn-on-mull-festival/history/ | title = History of the Mendelssohn on Mull Festival | publisher = Mendelssohn on Mull Festival | accessdate = 17 March 2017 }}</ref>
==History==
The festival was founded in 1988 by the violinist [[Leonard Friedman]], as a week of music-making, concentrating on string chamber music, where the participants were a blend of established professionals and students, at which audiences were welcome at no cost.<ref name="scotsman-25">{{cite news | url=http://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/culture/music/mendelssohn-on-mull-festival-marks-25th-anniversary-1-2975253 | title=Mendelssohn on Mull: Festival marks 25th anniversary | newspaper=[[The Scotsman]] | date=25 June 2013 | accessdate=17 March 2017}}</ref>
Following Friedman's death in 1994, the festival has maintained this pattern with artistic direction being provided by [[Levon Chilingirian]]<ref name=Guardian_2012>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2012/may/25/scotland-best-classical-music-festivals |author=Mark Porter |title=Scotland's best classical music festivals |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=25 May 2012 |accessdate=6 July 2018 |}}</ref> (2003–2016), and the [[Doric String Quartet]] (2018 to present).<ref>{{cite web| url= https://soundwavesscio.org.uk/mendelssohn-on-mull-festival/doric-string-quartet/ | title = Doric String Quartet at the Mendelssohn on Mull Festival | publisher = Mendelssohn on Mull Festival | accessdate = 17 March 2017 }}</ref>
The festival is administered by a trust which organises the events and pays the expenses of the participants and professionals. Since 2016 the festival has been administered by Sound Waves SCIO.<ref>http://www.oscr.org.uk/search-oscr/charity-details?number=SC044935</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://soundwavesscio.org.uk/mendelssohn-on-mull-festival/ Mendelssohn on Mull Festival web site]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Jennifer Ann Crecente | image = JenniferAnnCrecente.png | image_size = | caption = |birth_date = September 9, 1987 |birth_place = [[Las Cruces, New Mexico]] | death_date = February 15, 2006 (age 18) | death_place = Austin, Texas | death_cause = Murder by shooting | education = [[Bowie High School (Austin, Texas)|Bowie High School]] | parents = Drew and Elizabeth Crecente | website = [http://www.jenniferann.org Jennifer Ann's Group] }} '''Jennifer Ann Crecente''' (September 9, 1987 – February 15, 2006), a victim of [[teen dating violence]], was an 18-year-old high school student who was shot and killed in southwest [[Austin, Texas]] by Justin Crabbe, an ex-boyfriend, on February 15, 2006. Crecente's murder was the first in Austin in 2006.<ref>[http://www.texaspsyc.org/displaycommon.cfm?an=1&subarticlenbr=73 Texas Psychological Association]</ref> In response to her murder, two charitable organizations have been formed, a memorial grant created in her name, and legislation passed in Texas to prevent teen dating violence.
==Life== Jennifer Ann Crecente was born in 1987 in Las Cruces. Her family moved to Austin, where she attended local schools, including high school. Among her classmates at [[Bowie High School (Austin, Texas)|Bowie High School]] in Austin was Justin Crabbe, until he dropped out of school in the tenth grade.<ref>[http://www.kxan.com/Global/story.asp?S=4527453 "Crecente Murder Investigation Continues"], KXAN, Feb 20, 2006</ref>
Jennifer was a camp counselor at [[SciTrek]] in [[Atlanta]] and hospital volunteer in Austin.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elpasotimes.com/breakingnews/ci_6415655|title=Dating violence bill hopes to educate students|work=El Paso Times.com|accessdate=29 December 2014}}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Her grandmother was a psychologist and it was a field Jennifer was considering for study.
She and Crabbe dated for a period but she had ended their relationship. Crecente was killed a few months prior to graduation.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.lufkindailynews.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/capitolpressreleases/entries/2007/02/16/senator_shapleigh_files_jennif.html |title=''Lufkin Daily News'' |access-date=2007-07-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927094315/http://www.lufkindailynews.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/capitolpressreleases/entries/2007/02/16/senator_shapleigh_files_jennif.html |archive-date=2007-09-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
== Events == Jennifer Ann Crecente's body was found at night on February 16, 2006 in a wooded area in Austin.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.kvue.com/news/local/stories/021706ccklrKVUEbowie.3a26ecc9.html |title=KVUE TV |access-date=2006-10-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060821035029/http://www.kvue.com/news/local/stories/021706ccklrKVUEbowie.3a26ecc9.html |archive-date=2006-08-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Justin Crabbe, her ex-boyfriend, was arrested on February 18, 2006 on a charge of first-degree murder.<ref>[http://www.news8austin.com/content/your_news/default.asp?ArID=155865 News 8 Austin]</ref> Crabbe told police that he and a man named Richard were playing with a gun. Jennifer was about 20 to 30 feet away. The gun fired, and Jennifer fell to the ground. Crabbe did not check on Crecente to see how badly she was injured before fleeing the scene.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.tcfv.org/nulceus/deaths.php?itemid=216 |title=Texas Council on Family Violence |access-date=2006-10-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928022400/http://www.tcfv.org/nulceus/deaths.php?itemid=216 |archive-date=2007-09-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> A videotape showed Crabbe with another man purchasing ammunition at a sporting goods store.<ref>[http://www.kxan.com/Global/story.asp?S=4527453 KXAN TV]</ref> Crabbe was on parole from a prior felony conviction<ref>[http://www.kxan.com/Global/story.asp?S=4535397 KXAN TV]</ref> and could not legally purchase ammunition himself.
== Arrest and trial == Crabbe pleaded "not guilty" on September 22, 2006.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.txcn.com/sharedcontent/dws/txcn/austin/stories/092206kvuecrabbe-gv.84ea993.html |title=TXCN |access-date=2006-10-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928111142/http://www.txcn.com/sharedcontent/dws/txcn/austin/stories/092206kvuecrabbe-gv.84ea993.html |archive-date=2007-09-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> He was in jail and not eligible for bail. He faced a maximum sentence of life in prison.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.kvue.com/news/local/stories/092206kvuecrabbe-gv.84ea993.html |title=KVUE TV |access-date=2006-10-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927101110/http://www.kvue.com/news/local/stories/092206kvuecrabbe-gv.84ea993.html |archive-date=2007-09-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> On March 6, 2007, Crabbe's court-appointed lawyers requested to have his videotaped confession thrown out.<ref>Wattson, Gregg. [http://keyetv.com/topstories/local_story_065165154.html "Crabbe's Lawyers Fight To Throw Out Confession"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070310024641/http://keyetv.com/topstories/local_story_065165154.html |date=2007-03-10 }}, KEYE TV, March 6, 2007</ref> On March 22, 2007, Judge Charles "Charlie" Baird denied the defense's request to throw out the videotaped confession. Judge Baird set the trial date for July 23, 2007. On July 19, 2007, it was announced that there would be no trial for Crabbe but a court appearance has been scheduled for July 27, 2007.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.kvue.com/news/local/stories/071907kvueCrabbe-cb.8f3bc299.html |title=KVUE TV |access-date=2007-07-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927101001/http://www.kvue.com/news/local/stories/071907kvueCrabbe-cb.8f3bc299.html |archive-date=2007-09-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The court appearance was cancelled without explanation.
On July 31, 2007, it was announced that Crabbe had agreed to a guilty plea and that a hearing was scheduled for August 1, 2007. The terms were not released.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.statesman.com/news/content/news/stories/local/08/01/0801crabbe.html |title=''Austin-American Statesman:'' "Guilty plea expected in Bowie High death" |access-date=2007-07-31 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120911231605/http://www.statesman.com/news/content/news/stories/local/08/01/0801crabbe.html |archive-date=2012-09-11 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> On August 1, 2007, Crabbe pleaded guilty to murder as part of a plea agreement. He was sentenced to 35 years in prison. Additionally, he testified before a grand jury. Crabbe's testimony resulted in a sealed indictment for Ricardo Roman. Roman was indicted on July 17, 2007 and arrested on July 31, 2007 in South Texas.<ref>[http://www.statesman.com/news/content/news/stories/local/08/02/0802crabbe.html "Second suspect indicted in Bowie High student's death"] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120912174123/http://www.statesman.com/news/content/news/stories/local/08/02/0802crabbe.html |date=2012-09-12 }}, ''Austin-American Statesman,'' 2 August 2007</ref> On February 15, 2008, the Travis County District Attorney's office dismissed the indictment against Roman.<ref>[http://www.statesman.com/news/content/news/stories/local/02/16/0216roman.html "Murder charge dropped in teen's death; did prosecutors botch deal for testimony?"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080218191232/http://www.statesman.com/news/content/news/stories/local/02/16/0216roman.html |date=2008-02-18 }}, ''Austin-American Statesman'', 16 February 2008</ref>
== Charitable organizations == [[File:Day of the Dead altar.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Day of the Dead]] altar]] Both parents have founded organizations in Jennifer's honor. Organizational goals for the two organizations sometimes converge but work as individual entities:
[[Jennifer Ann's Group]], a [[501(c)(3)]] [[non-profit]] organization, was created by Jennifer's father Drew in February 2006 in Crecente's memory to prevent [[teen dating violence]]. The stated purpose of the organization is to "keep Jennifer Crecente's memory alive through education and good works." The organization distributes educational materials to schools and organizations across the US for free and has speakers for national and regional events to talk about teen dating violence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://JenniferAnn.org|title=Jennifer Ann's Group :: #stopTDV|publisher=|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> It is also the creator of the [http://www.jenniferann.org/games.htm Life.Love. Game Design Challenge], an annual video game design contest intended to educate teens and preteens about teen dating violence through online video games.<ref>[http://www.loveisrespect.org/2008/05/28/dating-abuse-game-design-winners/ Dating Abuse Game Design Winners] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121193332/http://www.loveisrespect.org/2008/05/28/dating-abuse-game-design-winners/ |date=2008-11-21 }} [[Loveisrespect, National Teen Dating Abuse Helpline]].</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesetwatch.com/2008/05/preventing_teen_dating_violenc.php|title=GameSetWatch Preventing Teen Dating Violence - The Game Competition Results|publisher=|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref>
Jennifer's Hope was founded in August 2006 by Jennifer's mother, Elizabeth Crecente. She speaks to teens and professionals, and has had several national appearances, multiple statewide appearances, and is involved in the Austin/Travis county community drives to prevent teen dating violence and promote healthy relationships.<ref>[http://www.jennifershope.org Jennifer's Hope]</ref>
== Memorial grant ==
The Texas Psychological Foundation<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.texaspsyc.org/displaycommon.cfm?an=1&subarticlenbr=174 |title=TX Psychological Assn: TPF Home<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=2006-10-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927180524/http://www.texaspsyc.org/displaycommon.cfm?an=1&subarticlenbr=174 |archive-date=2007-09-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> created The Jennifer Ann Crecente Memorial Grant<ref>[http://www.texaspsyc.org/displaycommon.cfm?an=1&subarticlenbr=73 Texas Psychological Foundation]</ref> in Crecente's memory. The annual grant pays $5,000 to a graduate student studying [[violence against women]]. Crecente's grandmother, Dr. Elizabeth Richeson,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.DrRicheson.com|title=El Paso Psychologist - Dr. Elizabeth L. Richeson, Ph.D.|publisher=|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> is a psychologist, and Crecente was considering a career in psychology.
== Legislation == On February 5, 2007, the Texas Legislature's State Representative Dawnna Dukes entered a bill to require school districts in Texas to create policies regarding [[Teen Dating Violence]]. This bill was created in memory of Jennifer Ann Crecente<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.oakhillgazette.com/default.asp?sourceid=&smenu=115&twindow=Default&mad=No&sdetail=420&wpage=&skeyword=&sidate=&ccat=&ccatm=&restate=&restatus=&reoption=&retype=&repmin=&repmax=&rebed=&rebath=&subname=&pform=&sc=1846&hn=oakhillgazette&he=.net |title=Oak Hill Gazette |access-date=2007-04-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928112906/http://www.oakhillgazette.com/default.asp?sourceid=&smenu=115&twindow=Default&mad=No&sdetail=420&wpage=&skeyword=&sidate=&ccat=&ccatm=&restate=&restatus=&reoption=&retype=&repmin=&repmax=&rebed=&rebath=&subname=&pform=&sc=1846&hn=oakhillgazette&he=.net |archive-date=2007-09-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> and Ortralla Mosley.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.statesman.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/capitolpressreleases/entries/2007/02/06/duke_works_to_protect_teens_fr.html |title=Austin-American Statesman |access-date=2007-02-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929122022/http://www.statesman.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/capitolpressreleases/entries/2007/02/06/duke_works_to_protect_teens_fr.html |archive-date=2007-09-29 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> [[Jennifer Ann's Group]] provided testimony on February 8, 2007 to the legislature in support of this bill. Governor [[Rick Perry]] signed the bill into law on May 18, 2007, and it immediately went into effect.<ref>[http://www.governor.state.tx.us/divisions/press/bills/bill_results Bills Signed by the Governor]</ref> Every school district in the state of Texas has to have a formal policy regarding Teen Dating Violence as a result of this legislation.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/04/us/04abuse.html ''New York Times'']</ref>
On February 15, 2007, on the one-year anniversary of Crecente's murder, Senator [[Eliot Shapleigh]] entered a bill to grant posthumous diplomas to students who died during their Senior year of high school. The bill is named "[[Jennifer's Law]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elpasotimes.com/search/ci_5238351|title=Bill would give slain students diplomas|work=El Paso Times.com|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> On May 28, 2007 the bill was signed in the Senate and passed to Governor [[Rick Perry]] for signing. The bill was signed by the Governor on June 15, 2007 and went into effect immediately.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legis.state.tx.us/billlookup/History.aspx?LegSess=80R&Bill=HB1563|title=Texas Legislature Online - 80(R) History for HB 1563|publisher=|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> "Jennifer's Law" allows the family of any Texas student who died during their [[Twelfth Grade|Senior]] year of high school to request a posthumous diploma.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.capitol.state.tx.us/tlodocs/80R/billtext/html/HB01563F.htm|title=80(R) HB 1563 - Enrolled version - Bill Text|publisher=|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref>
== Dedications == The [[Colquitt County]] Arts Center Theatre dedicated the 2007 production of ''[[Oliver!]]'' to Jennifer Ann Crecente. In 1998 the Arts Center had performed ''Oliver!'', and Jennifer and her father had both appeared in the production. The 2007 production is dedicated to Crecente because of her performance; in addition, the show includes a theme of [[dating violence]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.moultrieobserver.com/local/local_story_202222934.html |title=''Moultrie Observer:'' Play dedicated to slain teen |access-date=2007-07-22 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120910172552/http://www.moultrieobserver.com/local/local_story_202222934.html |archive-date=2012-09-10 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
== Footnotes == {{Reflist|2}}

{{Infobox Magazine | title = NIN
НИН | image_file = NINlogo.png | image_size = 200px | image_caption = | editor = Milan Ćulibrk | editor_title = Editor-in-chief | frequency = Weekly | circulation = | category = [[Newsmagazine]] | company = Ringier Axel Springer | publisher = [[Politika a.d.]] {{small|(1958–2007)}}
[[Ringier|Ringier Axel Springer d.o.o.]] {{small|(2009–present)}} | firstdate = 26 January 1935
7 January 1951
{{small|(re-established)}} | country = [[Serbia]] | language = [[Serbian language|Serbian]] | website = {{url|http://www.nin.co.rs/}} | issn = }} '''''NIN''''' ({{lang-sr-cyr|НИН}}) is a weekly [[newsmagazine]] published in [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]]. Its name is an [[acronym]] for '''''Nedeljne informativne novine''''' (Недељне информативне новине) which roughly translates into ''Weekly Informational Newspaper''. Though a current events magazine in its essence, ''NIN'' also earned an esteemed reputation due to a long tradition of opening its pages to the best and the brightest within [[Serbia]]n, and previously [[SFR Yugoslavia|Yugoslav]] society, whether in arts, sciences, or even sports. This reputation has recently somewhat been tarnished{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}} as the magazine was forced into commercial competition with numerous political periodicals that sprung up in [[Serbia]] after the collapse of [[socialism]]. Since then, ''NIN'' has adopted a slightly more populist tone, though it is still highly regarded. {{As of|2007}}, the magazine had 35 employees. In July 2008, the magazine celebrated the release of its 3000th issue.[http://www.politika.rs/rubrike/Drustvo/NIN-objavio-3000-broj.lt.html NIN objavio 3000. broj, ''Politika'', June 27, 2008] On March 13, 2009 it was announced that majority stake in the magazine was bought by Swiss media company [[Ringier AG]].[http://www.blic.rs/drustvo.php?id=83328 NIN prodat kompaniji "Ringier", ''Blic'', March 13, 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090314235159/http://www.blic.rs/drustvo.php?id=83328 |date=March 14, 2009 }} ==History== ''NIN'' was originally started in 1935.{{cite book|author=Robert Thomas|title=Serbia Under Milošević: Politics in the 1990s|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IDzmXEDJFX8C&pg=PR15|accessdate=2 August 2015|date=January 1999|publisher=C. Hurst & Co. Publishers|isbn=978-1-85065-367-7|page=15}} During the late 1980s [[Slobodan Milošević]] and his followers converted major publications, including ''NIN'', into media outlets of [[Serbian nationalism]].{{cite book|author=Richard West|title=Tito and the Rise and Fall of Yugoslavia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J34leeCdXFQC&pg=PT210|accessdate=24 April 2016|date=15 November 2012|publisher=Faber & Faber|isbn=978-0-571-28110-7|page=210}} ===2009 sale=== In 2007 ''NIN'' was preparing for [[privatization]].[http://www.b92.net/biz/vesti/srbija.php?yyyy=2007&mm=07&dd=27&nav_id=256974 NIN na aukciji 29. septembra, B92, July 27, 2007] At that time the magazine's ownership structure was: 87% publicly owned (društveni kapital), 10% owned by [[Politika AD]], and 3% owned by the employees. A 60.9% stake (70% of the public stake) in the magazine was to be auctioned off on September 29, 2007 with starting price set at [[Serbian dinar|RSD]]13.2 million (~ [[euro|€]]170,000).[http://www.b92.net/biz/vesti/srbija.php?yyyy=2007&mm=08&dd=28&nav_id=261073 Više od deset kupaca za NIN, B92, August 28, 2007] However, the auction as the method of privatization for the magazine was scrapped by the Serbian Privatization Agency due to employee demands and a new [[Tender offer|tender]] was set for sometime during spring 2008.[http://www.blic.co.rs/ekonomija.php?id=27214 Tender za NIN do kraja marta, ''Blic'', January 18, 2008] The tender was actually opened on October 30, 2008 and it closed on December 19, 2008. On December 25, 2008, it was reported that companies [[Ringier AG]] and [[Novosti AD]] submitted competing offers for 61.48% stake in ''NIN'' (70% of the magazine's public stake, which is in turn 87% of the total stake).[http://www.rts.rs/page/stories/ci/story/124/%D0%94%D1%80%D1%83%D1%88%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%BE/35451/%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%98%D0%B0+%22%D0%9D%D0%98%D0%9D%22-%D0%B0.html Продаја "НИН"-а, RTS, December 26, 2008] In mid March 2009, it was announced that Ringier AG bought the majority stake in ''NIN'' for RSD57.455 million (~ €810,000). Soon afterward the magazine's headquarters moved from Cetinjska Street to Kraljice Marije Street at the same location where ''[[Blic (newspaper)|Blic]]'' daily (Ringier's other major asset in Serbia) has its headquarters. Sometime in April 2009, longtime editor-in-chief Slobodan Reljić was let go and replaced with Srđan Radulović, up to that point an editor at ''Blic'' daily. The change was done quietly without any press releases. In September 2009, an open letter written by the magazine's longtime journalists to Ringier AG chairman [[Michael Ringier]] surfaced in which they are criticizing some of the moves and changes since Ringier took over.[http://www.pravda.rs/dogadjaji/12185/novi-anonimusi-unishtavau-nin Нови анонимуси уништавају НИН. ''Pravda'', September 14, 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090923170039/http://www.pravda.rs/dogadjaji/12185/novi-anonimusi-unishtavau-nin |date=September 23, 2009 }}[http://www.nspm.rs/hronika/pismo-novinara-nin-a-mihaelu-ringijeru.html Писмо новинара НИН-а Михаелу Рингијеру, ''NSPM'', September 14, 2009] ==The ''NIN'' Literary Award== In January every year, ''NIN''{{'}}s special jury vote on what they feel was the best novel released during the previous year and award it with ''[[NIN Prize|Ninova nagrada]]'' (Нинова награда, ''the NIN Prize''), which has over the years become one of the highest honours for contemporary Serbian authors. The award is also very relevant commercially as its recipients usually go on to become bestsellers. ==Editors== The list of individuals who performed editor-in-chief duties at ''NIN''. *[[Milan Ćulibrk]] May 2013 – Present *[[Nebojša Spaić]] October 2010 – May 2013 *[[Veselin Simonović]] ( acting editor-in-chief ) April 2010 – September 2010 *[[Srđan Radulović]] August 2009 – March 2010 *[[Slobodan Reljić]] October 2002 – July 2009 *[[Stevan Nikšić]] August 1998 – September 2002 *[[Milivoje Glišić]] March 1998 – August 1998 *[[Dušan Veličković]] March 1994 – February 1997 *[[Milo Gligorijević]] *[[Velizar Zečević]] *[[Teodor Anđelić]] *Mirko Đekić *Slava Đukić *Dušan Simić *Dragan Marković *Dragokjub Milivojević Uča *Frano Babieri *Đorđe Radenković *Stevan Majstorović *Najdan Pašić *Veselin Masleša Columnists for the magazine include the "king of sugar" businessman [[Miodrag Kostić]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.nin.co.rs/ Official Site] {{Serbian Newspapers}} [[Category:Magazines established in 1935]] [[Category:Media in Belgrade]] [[Category:News magazines]] [[Category:Serbian magazines]] [[Category:Serbian-language magazines]] [[Category:Weekly magazines]] [[Category:Communist magazines]] [[Category:Eastern Bloc media]] [[Category:Yugoslav magazines]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2)
revision.text:
The '''National Black Theatre Festival (NBTF)''' was founded in 1989 by [[Larry Leon Hamlin]] in [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina]]. Serving as its executive director, Hamlin’s goal in creating the Festival was "to unite black [[theatre]] companies in [[United States|America]] to ensure the survival of the genre into the next millennium".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://nbtf.org/nbtf_history.html | title=National Black Theatre Festival History Page | publisher=National Black Theatre Festival | year=2007 | accessdate=2007-06-08 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070703013428/http://www.nbtf.org/nbtf_history.html | archivedate=2007-07-03 | df= }}</ref> Held biennially since 1989 for six days, the NBTF showcases the best in [[African-American]] theater.
==Beginnings== As he was doing research for a magazine article in the late 1980s, Hamlin discovered a disconnect between the number of black theatre companies at that time. He concluded that a festival could serve as a method to bring these companies together, and he contacted renowned author and poet [[Maya Angelou]] for support. Together, they raised $500,000 in grants and contributions to finance the festival's operating costs.<ref name=robertson-larry>{{cite news | last = Robertson | first = Campbell | title = Larry Leon Hamlin, 58, Dies; Promoted Black Theaters | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/08/arts/08hamlin.html?ei=5088&en=4901c88d6649a970&ex=1338955200&adxnnl=1&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss&adxnnlx=1182960727-bVefLTqP+THfqm8Nz138hw | accessdate = 2007-06-27 | publisher = ''The New York Times'' | date=June 8, 2007}}</ref>
The first Festival attracted 10,000 people and offered 30 different performances by 17 of America’s best professional black theatre companies. Its theme was "An International Celebration and Reunion of Spirit". Angelou served as the Festival's first chairperson, and other prominent African-American performers lent their professional and financial support. It was covered by both the national and international media with wide acclaim.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://nbtf.org/nbtf_history.html | title=National Black Theatre Festival History Page | publisher=National Black Theatre Festival | year=2007 | accessdate=2007-06-27 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070703013428/http://www.nbtf.org/nbtf_history.html | archivedate=2007-07-03 | df= }}</ref>
==Challenges== The NBTF has been successful, but not without difficulties. In 2001, the Festival faced serious financial troubles that threatened its existence. Several funding sources reduced support and the budget for the Festival was left with a $300,000 deficit. In spite of this setback, Hamlin did not cancel the festival and was able to raise enough money to compensate the loss. He believed that African-American theatre was important and was able to make his dream a success.<ref name=armstrong-black>{{cite web | last = Armstrong | first = Linda | title = Black Theatre Family Holds Biannual Reunion; A firsthand report from the National Black Theatre Festival in Winston-Salem, N.C. | url = http://www.theatermania.com/content/news.cfm/story/1581 | accessdate = 2007-06-08 | year = 2001 | publisher = TheaterMania.com}}</ref>
==Today== The NBTF brings nearly 60,000 people to Winston-Salem.<ref name=dewan-six>{{cite news | last = Dewan | first = Sheila | title = A Six-Day Bash Celebrates Black Theater | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/06/theater/newsandfeatures/06fest.html?ex=1280980800&en=2a26eac01564f301&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland&emc=rss | accessdate = 2007-06-08 | publisher = ''The New York Times'' | date=August 6, 2005}}</ref> In addition to over 100 theatrical performances, highlights of the Festival are the Opening Night Gala, the Readers' Theatre of New Works, the Youth/Celebrity Project, International Colloquia, the International Vendor's Market, a poetry slam, and various workshops and seminars. More than 50 celebrities can be expected to attend the Festival during its run.
The 2007 festival was the first without the direct guidance of Hamlin, who died on June 6, 2007; organizers continued preparations though his presence was missed.<ref name="winsalemjournal">[http://www.journalnow.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=WSJ/MGArticle/WSJ_BasicArticle&c=MGArticle&cid=1173351523116 ''Winston-Salem Journal'': "Founder of National Black Theatre Festival dies"], June 6, 2007.</ref>
The 2009 NBTF was held August 3–8, 2009, with celebrity co-chairs [[Ted Lange]] and [[Wendy Raquel Robinson]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://nbtf.org/nbtf_history.html | title=National Black Theatre Festival History Page | publisher=National Black Theatre Festival | year=2008 | accessdate=2008-04-02 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070703013428/http://www.nbtf.org/nbtf_history.html | archivedate=2007-07-03 | df= }}</ref>
The 2011 NBTF was held August 1–6, 2011, with celebrity co-chairs [[Lamman Rucker]] and [[T'Keyah Crystal Keymáh]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://nbtf.org/ | title=National Black Theatre Festival Home Page | publisher=National Black Theatre Festival | year=2011 | accessdate=2011-06-02}}</ref>
The 2013 NBTF was held July 29-August 3, 2013, with celebrity co-chairs [[Tonya Pinkins]] and [[Dorien Wilson]]
The 2015 NBTF was held August 3-8, 2015, with celebrity co-chairs [[Debbi Morgan]] and [[Darnell Williams]].
The 2017 NBTF will be held July 31-August 5, 2017, with celebrity co-chairs [[Anna Maria Horsford]] and [[Obba Babatundé]].
==Notes and references== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book | last = Alkalimat | first = Abdul | authorlink = Abdul Alkalimat | title = The African American Experience in Cyberspace | year = 2003 | isbn = 978-0-7453-2222-3 | publisher = London: Pluto Press}}
==External links== * [http://www.ncblackrep.org/ The National Black Theatre Festival website] * [http://www.eurweb.com/story/eur10817.cfm THE NATIONAL BLACK THEATER FESTIVAL: Non-stop black theater at its best is on view all this week.] A 2003 article from EURweb.com about the festival.

Obtaining a money transfer by deception

revision.text:
'''Obtaining a money transfer by deception''' was formerly a statutory offence in [[England and Wales]] and [[Northern Ireland]].
==England and Wales== This offence was created by section 15A of the [[Theft Act 1968]]. Section 15B made supplementary provision. Both of those sections were inserted by section 1(1) of the [[Theft (Amendment) Act 1996]].
Section 15A was repealed on 15 January 2007<ref>The [[Fraud Act 2006 (Commencement) Order 2006]] (S.I. 2006/3200 (C.112)), [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2006/3200/article/2/made article 2]</ref> by sections 14(1) and (3) and 15(1) of, and paragraph 1(a)(ii) of Schedule 1 to, and Schedule 3 to, the [[Fraud Act 2006]], subject to transitional provisions and savings in paragraph 3 of Schedule 2 to that Act.
Section 15B was repealed on the same date<ref>The [[Fraud Act 2006 (Commencement) Order 2006]] (S.I. 2006/3200 (C.112)), [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2006/3200/article/2/made article 2]</ref> by sections 14(1) and (3) and 15(1) of, and paragraph 3 of Schedule 1 to, and Schedule 3 to, the [[Fraud Act 2006]].
The purpose of this offence was to fill the [[Lacuna (law)|lacuna]] in the law identified by the decision in ''R v Preddy and Slade, R v Dhillon''.<ref>[http://www.bailii.org/uk/cases/UKHL/1996/13.html R v Preddy and Slade, R v Dhillon] [1996] AC 815, [1996] 3 All ER 481, [1996] 3 WLR 255, (1996) 2 Cr App R 524, HL, (10 July 1996) reversing R v Preddy and Slade [1995] Crim LR 564, CA, and R v Dhillon, unreported, CA</ref> It implemented recommendations<ref>[[Law Commission (England and Wales)|The Law Commission]]. Offences of Dishonesty: Money Transfers. Law Com 123. HC vol 690. October 1996.</ref> of the [[Law Commission (England and Wales)|Law Commission]].<ref>[[Archbold Criminal Pleading, Evidence and Practice]], 1999, para. 12-212 at p. 1807</ref>
==Northern Ireland== This offence was created by section 15A of the [[Theft Act (Northern Ireland) 1969]]. Section 15B made supplementary provision. Both of those sections were inserted by article 3(1) of the [[Theft (Amendment) (Northern Ireland) Order 1997]] (S.I. 1997/277 (N.I. 3)).
Section 15A was repealed on 15 January 2007<ref>The [[Fraud Act 2006 (Commencement) Order 2006]] (S.I. 2006/3200 (C.112)), [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2006/3200/article/2/made article 2]</ref> by sections 14 and 15(1) and (4) of, and paragraph 1(c)(ii) of Schedule 1 to, and Schedule 3 to, the [[Fraud Act 2006]], subject to transitional provisions and savings in paragraph 3 of Schedule 2 to that Act.
Section 15B was repealed on the same date<ref>The [[Fraud Act 2006 (Commencement) Order 2006]] (S.I. 2006/3200 (C.112)), [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2006/3200/article/2/made article 2]</ref> by sections 14(1) and (3) and 15(1) and (4) of, and paragraph 9 of Schedule 1 to, and Schedule 3 to, the [[Fraud Act 2006]].
==References== *Smith, J. C. ''Money Transfers: "What Preddy did" to be an offence'' [1996] 9 Archbold News 4. {{reflist}}
{{English criminal law navbox}}

{{one source|date=July 2011}}
[[File:Gate of Old Jewish Cemetery Wrocław.jpg|thumb|Cemetery gate]] [[File:Hands motif.jpg|thumb|Hands motif]] The '''Old Jewish Cemetery in Wrocław''' is located in the southeast part of [[Wrocław]] (formerly known as Breslau), [[Poland]], currently along Ślężna street. The first burial took place on 17 November 1856 which back then was a village of Gabitz. The current shape of the cemetery evolved mostly during the 19th century, during the German period of the city. The cemetery area was expanded twice. In 1943 the burial ceremonies were abandoned and the necropoly was leased for five years to a gardening center. During [[World War II]], the cemetery became a fierce battleground, the marks of which are still visible on many [[tombstone]]s. After 1945 it slowly turned into ruins. It was put on the list of the city's monuments in 1975.
==Architecture==
Most of the cemetery objects were built in second half of the 19th century. They imitate various architectural styles including [[Ancient]], the [[Middle Ages]], [[Renaissance]], [[Baroque]]. Great example of Ancient architecture are numerous columns located throughout the cemetery that are symbols of life and eternity. Columns imitating broken trees reflect the tragedy of fragile life and death. Tombstones are signed by bilingual inscriptions, most commonly [[German language|German]] and [[Jewish languages|Jewish]].<ref name="Wroclaw">{{Cite book|title=Stary Cmentarz Żydowski we Wrocławiu|last=Łagiewski|first=Maciej|publisher=Via Nova}}</ref>
Most common symbols of Jewish culture which can be seen on tombstones are: * hands - on the tombstones of descendants of [[Aaron]] * oriental tree - ancient symbol of messianic hope * broken rose - motif of death * helmet - army officer symbol * palms - symbols of national sacrifice of Jews <ref name="Wroclaw" />
==Renowned people buried at the cemetery== * Isidor and Neander Alexander - renowned banker family<ref name="Wroclaw" /> * [[Leopold Auerbach]] - professor in biology and historogy at the University of Breslau (now [[University of Wrocław]]) * [[Ferdinand Cohn|Julius Cohn]] - professor of botanics * [[Heinrich Graetz]] - professor of history at Wrocław University * [[Friederike Kempner]] - writer * [[Ferdinand Lassalle]] - a thinker, labor leader, and social activist who stayed in close contact with [[Karl Marx]] and [[Friedrich Engels]]
==Antisemitic Incident==
On July 30, 2010, the Jewish cemetery in Wrocław was desecrated with swastikas drawings and vulgar graffiti. In addition, some of the gravestones were broken.<ref>{{cite web|title=Poland - Jewish cemetery desecrated|url=http://antisemitism.org.il/article/15974/poland-jewish-cemetery-desecrated|work=CFCA|publisher=CFCA|accessdate=5 December 2013}}</ref>
==Picture gallery== <gallery> File:Helmet motif.jpg|Helmet motif File:Leopold Aucherbach tombstone.jpg|Leopold Aucherbach tombstone File:Oriental tree symbol.jpg|Oriental tree symbol File:Tombstone destroyed during WWII.jpg|Tombstone destroyed during World War II File:Tombstone of Cohn family.jpg|Tombstone of Cohn family File:Broken tree.jpg|Broken tree </gallery>
==References== {{commons category|Wrocław Old Jewish Cemetery}} {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}

{{third-party|date=January 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox academic conference | logo = [[Image:Wikisym-logo.jpg|225px]]

''Logo of the 2008 conference'' | history = 2005– | discipline = [[wiki]] & [[open collaboration]] research | abbreviation = OpenSym / WikiSym | publisher = [[ACM Digital Library]] | country = International | frequency = annual | website = [http://www.opensym.org/ www.opensym.org] }} '''OpenSym''' is a shorthand for '''International Symposium on Open Collaboration''', formerly '''International Symposium on Wikis and Open Collaboration''', also formerly '''WikiSym''' or the ''Wiki Symposium'', a conference dedicated to [[wiki]] research and practice. In 2014, the name of the conference was changed from WikiSym to OpenSym to reflect a broadening of scope from wiki and Wikipedia research and practice to [[open collaboration]] research, including wikis and Wikipedia research, but also free/libre/[[open source]], [[open data]], etc. research. Its proceedings are published in the [[ACM Digital Library]]. ==Overview of conferences 2005-present== [[File:Aaron Halfaker y Stuart Geiger en OpenSym 2018.jpg|thumb|[[Aaron Halfaker]] y [[Stuart Geiger]] en OpenSym 2018]] {| class="wikitable" |+ WikiSym conferences !Conference !Date !Place !Proceedings |- |[http://www.wikisym.org/ws2005 WikiSym 2005] |14–16 October |{{Flag icon|US}} [[San Diego]], California, US |[http://www.wikisym.org/ws2005/proceedings/] |- |[http://www.wikisym.org/ws2006 WikiSym 2006] |21–23 August |{{Flag icon|Denmark}} [[Odense]], Denmark |[http://www.wikisym.org/ws2006/proceedings/] |- |[http://www.wikisym.org/ws2007 WikiSym 2007] |21–23 October |{{Flag icon|Canada}} [[Montreal]], Canada |
